DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. SIR ALAN HULME, KBE

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on Monday, 9 October 1989, of Sir Alan Hulme, KBE, a former member of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 9 October 1989, of the Honourable Sir Alan Hulme, KBE, a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Petrie from 1949 to 1961 and from 1963 to 1972, Minister for Supply from 1958 to 1961, Postmaster-General from 1963 to 1972 and Vice-President of the Executive Council from 1966 to 1972, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and the members of his family in their bereavement.

Sir Alan, who was born at Mosman, New South Wales, on 14 February 1907, was one of the founders of the Liberal Party, and entered parliament as a member of that Party in 1949. He represented the electors of Petrie for well over 20 years, serving under five Prime Ministers. He was Minister for Supply from 1958 to 1961; Postmaster-General from 1963 to 1972-the longest serving Postmaster-General-and Vice-President of the Executive Council from 1966 to 1972.

During his time in the House, Sir Alan served on numerous parliamentary committees. He was also Chairman of the Commonwealth Immigration Planning Council from 1956 to 1958. Alan Hulme was appointed Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire in January 1971. Sir Alan Hulme was a respected member of the Parliament for many years. He also served his Party well, having been President of the Queensland branch on two occasions-from 1946 to 1949, and from 1962 to 1963. On behalf of the Government I extend to his family our sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in support of the motion and in expressing our sympathy to the family of the late Sir Alan Hulme. Sir Alan Hulme was one of that generation of Liberal members of parliament who served during the 1949 to 1972 period, although he was absent from one parliament following the election in 1961 which, honourable senators will recall, was won narrowly by the Menzies Government. Apart from that he was part of that unbroken period of 23 years of Liberal and National Party governments and he played a distinguished role in them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Government has already mentioned the particular ministerial functions that Sir Alan Hulme undertook as Minister for Supply and as Postmaster-General. In addition, he was an important supporter and confidante of Sir Robert Menzies. He played a distinguished role with, I think, the father of Senator Walters in providing very strong personal support for Australia's longest serving Prime Minister. He probably made his most distinguished contribution to government as Postmaster-General. Looking at the record of some of his period, I am pleased to say that he did not fulfil one of his ambitions, which was to see a telephone in every room in Australia. It seems to me that that would have made what is often an uncomfortable life in politics even more uncomfortable. I am pleased that in that respect Sir Alan did not achieve his stated ambition.

Sir Alan presided over the then Post Office at a time of developments of very great importance in terms of the introduction of television, first black and white and later colour television. He was there for the introduction of international subscriber trunk dialling. He presided over a period of very great technological change and expansion. When he left the Parliament temporarily in 1961 he immediately resumed service to the Liberal Party and resumed his presidency of the Party in Queensland. He made an outstanding and consistent contribution to the fortunes of his Party over most of his life. It was a distinguished contribution. He was a man who was described as dour but who was warmly regarded by many people. The Opposition deeply regrets his death and expresses sympathy for his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government, Senator John Button, and extend our sympathy and condolences to the family of the late Sir Alan Hulme.

—I want to put on the public record my sadness at the passing of Sir Alan Hulme. Sir Alan was a great representative of the Parliament and a great Queenslander. He was very active in the Liberal Party. He was very active in the early years when I started my association with the Liberal Party, in the mid-1960s. Sir Alan Hulme was a man of very great integrity and purpose. He was one of the pillars of the Menzies Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add some words to this motion of condolence. Not only was Sir Alan Hulme one of the founders of the political party to which I belong, and a forty-niner-one of that great band of people who entered Parliament in the sweeping Menzies win of 1949-but also he was a person who knew the bitterness of 1961 and who still came back and served what for many people would be another full parliamentary career. There are very few forty-niners left. I have frequent communications from the Hon. William Charles Wentworth IV, who I would say to Bill if he is listening, keeps me busy and active. I would like to support Senator MacGibbon's comment that Sir Alan was a great Queenslander, but he was more than that. He occupied most positions within the Government and, I understand, served for longer than anyone else in the portfolio of Postmaster-General.

SPEECH.PARA: Some years ago, in 1974-75, I was President of the Gordon Branch of the Liberal Party, a very large branch, of over 600 members. Following my election to this Parliament, I think the next President was a friend of Senator Chaney's, a former Western Australian by the name of Mr Mason-Jones. I think Senator Chaney would remember him. Sir Alan Hulme's son, Robert Hulme, succeeded him. Robert Hulme is a member of the Gordon Branch of the Liberal Party. We got to know him very well and to appreciate what he is and what he stands for. He is a barrister in Sydney. But more than that, we got to know from him some of the history of the family and some of the travails that his father went through in beginning, continuing and achieving his eminent career. I say to Robert Hulme that it is appropriate today that in the Senate we pay tribute to his father and put on record all that his father stood for. We say to the Hulme family that this is a story of a job well done.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 203 citizens) and Knowles (from 2,339 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania, Television Transmissions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State;
That more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from the VHF to the UHF band;

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Giles (from 102 citizens), Jones (from 57 citizens) and Patterson (from 134 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled.
The honourable petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987-88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortions.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 15 citizens), Jones (from five citizens) and Messner (from 28 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray.

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists, leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: A NATIONAL CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, will be absent from the chamber for Question Time this week on official Government business overseas. —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to the Government's Newstart program which is aimed at assisting the long-term unemployed in the 21 to 54 age group whose numbers last financial year averaged 116,000. Will the Minister confirm that, as a result of approaches by the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service to the end of June to a sample of something over 10,000 of those long-term unemployed, 12 per cent of those approached had their unemployment benefit cancelled and not reinstated within six weeks? Will the Minister further confirm that another 13 per cent of this group had their level of payment reduced, making a total of 25 per cent who lost either the whole or part of the benefit? Is it also a fact that of those who made it to the interviews-to move on to another group of the same sample-a total of 14 per cent commenced employment, 6 per cent began a Department of Employment, Education and Training labour market program, and 8 per cent commenced some other form of educational training or had left the labour force? In view of these quite remarkable figures from this pilot program, does the Minister agree that there is room for further major savings in this area? Does the Government have any details subsequent to those included in the last Budget Papers from which I have quoted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated by Senator Chaney I have not got precise figures on this particular question. At the outset I will respond to the point about those who have been interviewed under the Newstart program. I make the basic point that Newstart and the value of it may be underscored by the statistics that Senator Chaney puts forward-if, in fact, they are accurate. On the question of unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment, the reality is that the Government has put in place a comprehensive program geared towards assisting transition to work. To that extent we have the Newstart and jobs, education and training (JET) programs that are geared towards problems with long-term unemployment. Essentially, this involves meshing together labour market programs, education, training and the social security system. This Government, unlike previous conservative governments in particular, has been quite relaxed about letting people stay on unemployment benefits. I point out that when Senator Chaney was a Minister for this area a number of criteria and checks were done away with to ensure that only those who were genuinely unemployed did, in fact, receive unemployment benefits. The Government's approach-this is consistent with all our approaches in the social security area-is that this area be tackled comprehensively. As a consequence, Newstart is a program which meshes together the need to ensure that retraining programs are in place. If Senator Chaney's figures are accurate one can contend quite strongly that one of the important aspects of the Government's policy-to ensure that those genuinely in need receive assistance-is being met. To that extent I do not know what particular point Senator Chaney is making other than one that rebounds on him.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the second part of Senator Chaney's question about whether there is any further scope for savings in the unemployment area, unlike a statement delivered last week, this Government has consistently and comprehensively over our period of office tackled the problem of fraud in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —You made unemployment a way of life.

—Senator Stone says that we made unemployment a way of life. Let me respond to that. Over the last six years this Government has created 1.6 million jobs. We have provided incentives for unemployed people to take part-time or casual work and to move into full-time employment. As a consequence, these schemes are enmeshed in that. Let me also say that this approach is starting to work and is having a major impact particularly on that area that Senator Stone seems to be concerned about. He has dragged Senator Chaney along on a chain on this question of the longer term unemployed. From 1986 to May 1989 we have had something like 500 longer term unemployed per week coming off the unemployment list. Senator Stone might sigh but the difference between our policies and his is that ours are not derived out of prejudice and long lost ideology. Another thing that the Opposition needs to notice is that in 1984 the total number of people receiving the unemployment benefit was about 670,000. Senator Chaney should know that. He was the responsible Minister at that time. As of Friday this number has fallen to 363,000-an average of 2,000 per week over the last three years. If we are talking about creating an unemployment mentality, let us compare the records. This Government has shown a commitment to controlling fraud in this area. Our commitment has been shown and well demonstrated by our targeting particular areas, particularly through our mobile review teams which, I am sure, Senator Chaney has also acknowledged in the past as having a major impact in this area. Senator Chaney should not come in here being vague, suffering from amnesia and not recognising what this Government has been doing in the area of employment, unemployment and social security fraud.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. I thank the Minister for giving us a prepared answer to a question he was not asked. I now direct his attention to the question I did ask. Is the Minister casting doubts on the explanatory material given to the Senate just a few weeks ago about the Newstart program and the substantial proportion of long term unemployed shown to be able to be shifted off unemployment benefits? Secondly, in light of that, does the Minister agree that there is room for further major savings in this area? Does he have details about the Newstart program additional to those which were tabled some weeks ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying nothing of the sort and I will not have Senator Chaney putting words into my mouth on this.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The reality is-I have said this before and I will say it again-that the Government has consistently had a program in this area for longer term unemployed. We will not respond to the problem in a knee-jerk way, as the Opposition has. We will not appeal to prejudice. As, I think, the Sydney Morning Herald said on the weekend, the Opposition seems to be more concerned about politics than responsible policy and economics.

ANSWER.PARA: The reality is that this Government will not target the longer term unemployed and isolate them in the community. Our policy response in this area has, like most others, been driven by the Social Security Review-a review which, I suggest, would be good reading for Senator Chaney. He would find from that review that the sorts of people he is talking about are quite often older unemployed-those with families and those who, through no fault of their own, are on the unemployment list. So our response will not be arbitrary; it will be comprehensive and detailed. To that extent, we have implemented fraud control in this area over the last six years. Our response to fraud in this area is not the across-the-board response of the Opposition. We will not target a particular doctor and say that any person going to that doctor will not be able to get sickness benefits. This is what Senator Chaney said in regard to the Greek social security case-a case which was born out of prejudice and a lack of comprehensive policy detail and which cost the taxpayers of this country $20m rather than gained money for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the latest hot-air ballooning tragedy, which claimed the lives of two people near Cessnock in the Hunter Valley on Sunday, 15 October, bringing the total of deaths from three such accidents to 17 in the past two months, discounting a fourth accident which seriously injured six people. In view of these alarming accidents, will the Government give urgent consideration to grounding all hot-air balloons, pending a detailed report into all aspects of ballooning and the general safety of the sport?

—I do not think the Government, at this stage, will accede to the request in Senator Jones's question, but it may do in time. Of course, there is concern about the recent series of accidents. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is examining the causes of these accidents. The safety of ballooning, like that of all aviation activities, is the responsibility of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). I understand that the CAA held discussions today with the ballooners association in relation to the recent spate of accidents. At this stage the causes of the accidents appear largely unrelated. Any action to suspend commercial balloon operations would be a matter for the CAA. The CAA has arranged a meeting with commercial balloon operators and the Australian Ballooning Federation to review the relevant standards and procedures. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation will be closely involved in this process. I should make the point that Australian commercial balloon pilot requirements are much more stringent than those of most other countries and, in particular, more stringent than those in the United States of America.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the worrying developments last Friday on the New York Stock Exchange and to the sharp falls this morning, both in our stock market and in the value of the Australian dollar. Without in any way seeking to predict the final outcome in either of these areas, I ask: Firstly, is it not deplorable that, after 6 1/2 years of this Labor Government, our debt-laden and hot money-financed economy should now have become so vulnerable to the slightest breath of adverse news from abroad? Secondly, does the Treasurer intend to make any statement on these matters or is he still in hiding as he has been ever since the Opposition announced last Thursday its Economic Action Plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Treasurer were in hiding, the only place that he would find the Opposition would be if he were hiding in a cave. Senator Stone's question is absolutely ridiculous. I do not intend to respond to the first part about it being deplorable, et cetera.
—Bring back Walshy.

—I will put on my grumpy mood in a moment and do a real `Walsh' if the Opposition does not behave itself. The first part of the question asks me to comment on what happened in New York and whether it has effect here. It had effect in New Zealand and in Hong Kong. As the financial markets open all around the world, it will have an effect there. It probably will not have the effect that Senator Stone predicted in his very erudite but totally inaccurate article about the effects of the October 1987 crash. We now auction Senator Stone's economic predictions at Australian Labor Party raffles. One cannot find anything that is even remotely as inaccurate as those were.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question asked when the Treasurer was coming out of hiding. The Treasurer has been very active in the last few days, as I have noticed from news programs. He has delivered the John Curtin Memorial Lecture and has given a whole series of interviews. I do not know where Senator Stone has been in the last two or three days to have missed that. The implication in his question was that, in some way, the Treasurer would be going into hiding because the Opposition has announced its alternative economic policy. I remind Senator Stone of some of the things that the Opposition has picked up in its alternative policy. We have had to put up for years in this chamber with Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Panizza going on ad nauseam about gold tax. What has the Opposition picked up in its policy? Gold tax. We have listened to the Opposition ad nauseam going on about fringe benefits tax. An integral part of the Opposition's economic package is the fringe benefits tax. We have listened to the Opposition going on and on about capital gains tax. The Opposition withdraws capital gains tax and substitutes something of a similar ilk. We heard Senator Stone say how the Opposition was going to get rid of the assets test; yet it has picked all that up in its economic policy.

What the Opposition has done is pick up the basic economic prescriptions of this Government, as expressed in the Forward Estimates, where we have done all the hard work and the Opposition has been on the sideline whingeing and complaining all the way through. The Opposition never wants to do any of the tough things. When it comes to the crunch, the Opposition will let us do the tough things and then the Opposition will cop it without changing it when it gets into government. The Opposition's only contribution in all this is to say, `We will accept all those parameters, but we will do a little switch in the middle. We will take $2 billion off those who really need it and give it to other people as an electoral bribe'. That is how far the Opposition has come in terms of economic policy. Why should the Treasurer have to hide from any of that? As I said to Senator Chaney by way of interjection earlier on, the Opposition is just a bunch of Gordon Geckos.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Stone for a supplementary question, let me say that there were too many interjections from the Opposition benches during Senator Ray's previous answer. I request silence during this answer.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. By way of correction to the Minister's response, I note that the Treasurer has not been delivering the John Curtin Memorial Lecture. I think that was delivered by Minister Howe. Be that as it may, will the Minister confirm that about a month ago the Treasurer told the Press Gallery with much flourish and eclat that he was not going to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings this year because he wanted to stay home and deal with the Opposition's tax policy? Will the Minister confirm that the Treasurer has been reported as saying that he was proposing to tear this policy to shreds when it was announced and has been reported on several occasions as waiting to blow it out of the water when it finally appeared? Does the Minister recall the dramatic presentation of the cobra ready to strike? Will the Minister now confirm, in the light of these remarkable presentations by the Treasurer, that his singular absence from the firing line in the four days that have now elapsed since the Opposition's tax policy was announced would render one open to the view that the cobra has become a carpet snake?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know about carpet snakes but what a sad metamorphosis from an economic rationalist or carpetbagger is reflected in that question. Senator Stone can play a lot of roles in this chamber but as an utterer of cheap political rhetoric he is not even in the business.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections from the Opposition. Senator Ray is entitled to be heard.

—I have a louder voice, Mr Deputy President, that I can go to-defcon five-but I would rather not. Poor old Senator Stone is really trying to go down the economic populist road. He comes in here and tries to be funny about snakes. If I were to carry that analogy too far I would be very hurtful to him personally, so I will not do so. The fact remains that the Opposition's alternative economic policy reflects a lot of the basic economic parameters of this Government and then just adds to them. I would say what the Treasurer would say: having regard to Senator Stone's whingeing, whining and carryings-on over the last four or five years, when it comes to the crunch of producing an alternative policy, all of his micro-gripes are not picked up. He has accepted the basic macro approach of this Government; he has accepted the estimates and forward estimates. The only variation he has is based not on economics but on a supposed appeal to the electors. I say to Opposition senators right now that if that is the price they have to pay to win, it is not worth paying. If they want to bludge on the less well-off in our society, diverting income from them to give to the better off-and that is what they are doing-they are welcome to it. As far as we on this side are concerned, we will always stand for looking after the less well-off in the community.

—Is the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of reports of a further recent oil spill at a United States base in the Antarctic? What lessons can be drawn from such incidents in the context of the present international debate over the future of Antarctica?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been concerned to hear reports of two recent fuel oil spills at a United States station in Antarctica. The first, said to be up to 200,000 litres, was discovered in late September at the United States South Pole base. The second, reportedly involving up to 225,000 litres of jet fuel, diesel oil and petrol, was discovered on 11 October at Williamsfield Air Base on McMurdo Sound near the coast. In response to our inquiries United States agencies have limited comment to acknowledgment of the leaks, their causes and rectification and, in the case of McMurdo, the fact that clean-up of the area has begun. The United States Science Foundation maintains that when the clean-up is completed environmental impact is expected to be minimal.

ANSWER.PARA: These latest examples of oil spills in Antarctica are only a small example of what might occur if Antarctica were to be opened to large scale mineral resource activity. Such accidents would more likely than not occur in the sensitive ice-free areas around the coast or at sea and the impact of a spill on wildlife and on the fragile environment generally would be very great indeed. I make the point that this year, 1989, there have been four oil spills from various countries' bases or Antarctic vessels, other than those of the United States. From this sort of record the argument that such accidents should be effectively guarded against and prevented under the Antarctic Minerals Convention is manifestly not credible. It is hard enough to prevent spills from existing lower levels of non-resourced based activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of media reports that the environmental impact statement for the relocation of naval facilities to Jervis Bay is proceeding to completion without any further studies of alternative schemes? What is being done to implement the Prime Minister's directive that alternatives to the relocation plan are to be considered? Finally, will the alternative schemes to be considered include retaining the fleet base in Sydney and possibly relocating the armament depot and selected fleet base functions further north?

—I have not seen those reports. I know that discussions have taken place between the Prime Minister and other relevant Ministers about this issue and I will try to obtain some further information for Senator Sanders. I must say, however, that the Government has made no decision to proceed with a fleet base relocation from Sydney and will not do so unless it is satisfied that the environmental factors and all relevant information have been examined objectively.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of a recent claim by the shadow Minister for science and energy, Mr Peter McGauran, that the Government has backed away from its target of one billion trees planted by the year 2000? Is there any basis for Mr McGauran's claim? Is the target of one billion trees realistic, and how will it be achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to those questions are yes, no and yes. I am aware that Mr McGauran's claim was reported in the Sunraysia Daily of 6 October under the heading `McGauran claims Government admits tree program failure'. Mr McGauran is reported as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Resources Minister, Senator Peter Cook, stated in the Senate Estimates Committee on September 28 that he had stopped talking about planting one billion trees.

At that point the article went on to extrapolate this whole feeble argument. I can only say that Mr McGauran, either through ignorance or deliberately, in this case is misrepresenting what I said in the Senate Estimates Committee. What I said in the Senate Estimates Committee can be seen by consulting Hansard of Estimates Committee F on 28 February. I said:
I have stopped talking about planting one billion trees. I have altered my language to talk about growing one billion trees. I acknowledge your point-
referring to a point made by Senator Brownhill-

that often social plantings mean that people make the commitment, go and plant a tree but do not ensure that it is fertilised properly, protected from grazing cattle or scavengers and that it survives until it has a healthy growth and continues to grow.

I was responding to a constructive intervention in the Senate Estimates Committee by Senator Brownhill about how, once we plant these trees, we make sure that they survive to grow properly. From that comment Mr McGauran has made his outrageous and inaccurate claim. One can only consider that he is deliberately or unknowingly misrepresenting the truth. I said in that exchange in the Senate Estimates Committee that the Government has not backed away from the billion trees initiative announced by the Prime Minister in the environment statement in July. Despite what Mr McGauran has said, the Government never said that it would plant and look after one billion trees by itself. Rather, we will be giving encouragement, advice and incentives to the whole community so that Australians as a whole will grow one billion trees by the year 2000. We are aiming to have 400 million trees planted and a further 600 million trees grown by direct seeding and natural regeneration under the one billion trees program. These figures do not include regeneration of existing forests, as suggested by Mr McGauran, which is another inaccuracy in his press statement. I can report that already Victoria and Western Australia have announced State schemes to grow more trees-100 million under the Tree Victoria program in Victoria and 200 million in Western Australia. I am sure that other States will emulate those programs. The Commonwealth will allocate-this is Senator Richardson's area, not mine, and he is in charge of that program, not me-

TALK.START.PARA: —Just in case it fails.

—No. It is a clear initiative from the environmental perspective and something that I would have thought Senator Puplick would have more than an hysterical interest in. The Commonwealth will be allocating an additional $4m each year to Greening Australia from 1989-90, bringing its total support for the decade of the 1990s to $47m. Those who are quick at mental arithmetic-everyone on this side of the chamber and no-one on the other side-will realise that that amounts to just under 5c for each of the one billion trees.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly and realistically, the Government is looking to the participation of the whole community in planting and caring for trees in order to reach the target of one billion trees, and I have no doubt about our capacity to deliver. However, I question why a community initiative of this character, which has the widespread support of the environmental movement, community organisations around Australia, shire and local government authorities as well as farmers and other groups, should be torpedoed by the small-minded, petty point-scoring of the type which Mr McGauran came out with in early October.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the Minister recall telling the Senate on 5 October that Ansett Airlines of Australia had been paid $701,735 for what is described as `net employee cost equivalence' between 28 August and 11 September? What further claims have been made to the Government, or payments approved by it, for compensation to the domestic airlines for the cost of paying the wages of employees who would otherwise be stood down because of no work? Can the Minister also advise the Senate of the net cost to the Government so far of the massive Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) involvement in the present makeshift domestic air services, so that the public will know the full extent of the direct and indirect subsidy being provided by this Government as a result of the decision to compensate the airlines selectively?

—First of all, there are a number of assumptions in the question which I do not share or wish to comment about in great detail. In answer to the specific points made by Senator Brownhill, sure, I gave the figure he mentioned to the Senate a week or two ago. I will find out what further payments have been made and provide the honourable senator with an answer. As for the costs to the Government and the taxpayer as a result of the use of RAAF services, I will attempt to obtain a figure on that and provide him with the answer. The assumption is that somehow the costs which have been incurred to the Australian community might have been avoided by acceding to the pilots claim. That is an assumption which the Government does not share.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Minister seen a report in this morning's Canberra Times which states that a University of Queensland anthropologist is suggesting that half of the fish population of the Great Barrier Reef will be destroyed by 1991 because of `a huge amount of waste from mining in Papua New Guinea'? Can the Minister comment on the accuracy of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen that report. In fact, that claim from a Queensland University anthropologist-whose name, I think, is Hyndman-has been around in some student newspapers for some time, which has given the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority an opportunity to examine it. The Authority is at a loss to explain the claim. There is obviously a significant problem with the Ok Tedi mine in particular. Like many honourable senators, I am sure, I have been disturbed to read that not only is a huge sediment load now coming down the Fly River but also, because of the failure of the tailings dam, there is considerable leaching of heavy metals. The effects of those on Torres Strait are as yet unknown. The Australian Government is committed under the Torres Strait Treaty to protect Torres Strait, and no doubt we will live up to our obligations. As a first step, the Prime Minister announced in his environment statement a commitment of $150,000 this year and $200,000 next year to have a baseline study conducted so that we can see what there is of the environment and then be able to monitor the effects of mining, from Ok Tedi in particular, over time. I hope that some arrangements can be made between the company and the Papua New Guinea Government so that this great danger to at least the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef and to the Torres Strait can be minimised. Certainly that does not appear to be the case at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister, representing the Prime Minister, Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport and Communications. At what point will the Government expect the domestic airlines to cease relying on a taxpayer subsidy to meet the cost of the Australian Council of Trade Unions' (ACTU) ultimatum on no stand-downs? In other words, what alleged level of scheduled services will need to be reached before the Government says to the airlines that the arrangement is over? Will this not happen until 100 per cent of normal domestic services are restored using the airlines' own aircraft and staff? If so, and given that no-one expects this to happen for many months, what is the Government's current estimate of the likely cost of the direct subsidy in view of the fact that a two-week claim by Ansett Airlines has already cost taxpayers more than $700,000?
—Those are matters which will be determined from time to time.
—It is open-ended.

—Senator Chaney says that it is open-ended. But, for goodness sake, does one make calculations on the basis that the pilots strike will last another eight weeks? I would have thought not. That will be determined from time to time. If Senator MacGibbon asks me again in two weeks' time or four weeks' time and the strike is continuing, we will provide him with an assessment.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. In so far as everyone accepts that by paying this demand of the ACTU the Government is prolonging the strike, would the Government not have a vested interest in putting a finite termination before the airlines so that they can resolve the dispute and cease their lock-out tactics and perpetuation of the strike?
—Not everybody agrees with that assumption; I do not, and it is not particularly relevant to the issue.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security a question about the administration of sickness benefit. Is it a fact that there has been a substantial tightening of the administration of sickness benefit by this Government? Does the Minister see any scope for a further modification of the rules in this area, as recently proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates demonstrates his long interest in this area by his assertion in the first part of the question.
—What, his capacity to read a prepared question?

—Despite Senator Chaney's long interest, he is still lost. As Senator Coates indicated, the Government's approach has been comprehensive, has been based on empirical evidence and forms part of a very coherent long term policy. In 1987 we commenced our measures in this area by removing an anomaly which was introduced under the previous Liberal Government. This anomaly made sickness benefits payable at a higher rate than unemployment benefits. We felt that this incentive was inappropriate. We had to facilitate the scheme so that people would not detach themselves from the labour market. So in 1987 we removed that anomaly. In 1987 we also introduced selective and medical reviews for sickness beneficiaries, concentrating on those most at risk of wrong payment. In fact, in 1988 we overhauled procedures for doctors to advise of incapacities. This year we have taken measures to ensure that sickness benefit cannot be received during a period of unused annual leave. We have also introduced additional selective and medical reviews for people on sickness benefits. As honourable senators should know, we are introducing mobile review teams in this area, building on the experience of the last two years of measures and targeting people at risk of wrong payment. When one looks at these measures one can see, once again, the Government's long analysis and coherent policy responses to this problem.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Coates also referred to recently floated proposals, I presume that he meant suggestions, made by the Opposition and, I think, Senator Chaney's committee. The Government's approach to this area is very different from the one proposed by the Opposition. The Opposition says that as a fundamental part of its policy it will reject the certificates of general practitioners when people apply for sickness benefits. Treating doctors will never be permitted to assess whether a person is unable to work because of illness. Their function will be replaced by government-employed medicos-a whole different breed of doctors-and, as a consequence, the doctor treating the person involved will be excluded from the decision making process. What the Opposition is saying basically is that no treating doctor can be trusted. Obviously that has cost implications in terms of employing doctors.

However, the Government is concerned that its policy be based on empirical evidence and careful analysis. In that respect, one wonders on what basis the Opposition has come up with such an idea. It has not asked one question of the relevant Minister during this session of Parliament. The data presented by the Social Security Review does not support the Opposition. Common experience-I am sure that Opposition senators have made this point more strongly than many others-suggests that most doctors are honest and professional. There is no real empirical evidence or support for the Opposition's proposition in this area.

The only precedent we could find was very much the response which goes back to 1979 and which spawned the Greek conspiracy case. The benefits of hundreds of people were cancelled merely because they went to the particular doctor. It is a similar prejudice which drives Opposition policy in this area. It comes as no surprise because for three years after the Greek conspiracy case-after `Don's party'-Senator Chaney, who was the Minister for Social Security, did nothing to have the benefits and pensions restored to the hundreds of people who had been illegally denied support. He did nothing to ensure accountability in the prosecutions and he did nothing to remedy the gross injustices. Rather, at that time we had a policy spawned in a belief that a treating doctor was not the appropriate person to make a judgment. In the social security area, the Government has based its policy responses on empirical evidence and careful analysis. We have also been keen to ensure that administration costs have been kept to a minimum. The Opposition's policy will do nothing of the sort.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister, and also representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Transport and Communications.
—Not the Minister for empiricals.

—Not the Minister for empiricals. Is the Minister aware of the continuing chaos which prevails in Australia's domestic airline services which makes a mockery of a claimed 60 per cent-plus level of normal carrying capacity? Does the Minister realise that people trying to travel regularly receive conflicting advice from the airlines about whether a service is operating at all, that scheduled services are suddenly said to have huge waiting lists and that previously promised flights are cancelled at short notice? If the Minister wants an example of what I have said I suggest that he look at Peter Ruehl's column in today's Australian Financial Review. I ask the Minister: When does the Government believe that there will be some prospect of a return to anything approaching normality in domestic airline services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A return to normality will come about when members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots agree to negotiate with the airlines. When I say `members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots', I am referring to the former employees of the airlines whom the Pilots Federation still purports to represent. I am aware of some of the matters which Senator Lewis raised. He referred to references which have been made to 60 per cent capacity in the airlines. I answered that question in this place a week or so ago. In answering that question I made the point at the time that if a fixed number of seats is provided on the two domestic airlines when they are normally operating, the number of seats being provided by the services now in place is equivalent to 60 per cent of that normal number. As I said at the time, that does not mean that adequate services are being provided to many places. They are not. That is clearly understood.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that people get conflicting advice about air services. My experience is that even when the airlines are operating one gets conflicting advice about airline services and cancellations at short notice, the sorts of things which Senator Lewis has mentioned. But it is not pretended that we have a fully adequate domestic air service at present. We do not. When the issues in dispute are resolved hopefully we will again have a fully adequate domestic air service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Is not the shortage of check and training captains employed by the domestic airlines a major impediment to the speedy processing of pilots who have applied for jobs with the airlines?
—That is not a supplementary question. I will seek to obtain an answer to it, nonetheless.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of warnings by Dr Brian Cooke, a senior researcher in South Australia's Animal and Plant Control Commission of rabbit plagues in a widespread area of South Australia and across parts of the Northern Territory, Queensland and New South Wales? What is the extent of the problem as far as soil erosion is concerned and what measures is the Commonwealth adopting to overcome the problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the significance of the rabbit plague in Australia; it is a major cause of land degradation in this country. It is one of our greatest pests in the pastoral industry. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) has estimated a national annual loss of $90m due to income forgone because of the competition rabbits provide for grazing stock. A separate estimate of $17m for South Australia alone was prepared by the ABARE. Rabbits have a significant effect upon the environment, particularly in semi-arid regions where, together with sheep, they have fundamentally altered the arid ecosystems. The disappearance of small marsupials, such as bilbies and hare-wallabies, is reputed to have occurred only after areas were invaded by rabbits. Rabbits are a major contributor to soil erosion, as I have said.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has committed itself to investigate further control methods to reduce the population of rabbits in Australia. Their population is, of course, automatically reduced at times of drought, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is perfecting a new form of transmissible disease which can be adapted to the rabbit plague and which, I believe, will have a significant effect in reducing one of the most serious threats to our ecosystem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the fact that interstate flights to and from Western Australia are running at no more than 25 per cent of the rate of normal service, in contravention of the claim that services are 62 per cent back to normal, will the Government make any request to the airlines to devote a greater share of their resources to the maintenance of air communications with Western Australia? Does the Government consider that the airlines ought to provide better services when they are in receipt of massive taxpayer subsidies? Does the Government recognise that the cancellation of scheduled flights caused by pilots running out of flight hours has rendered air communications unstable and unreliable? If so, what is the Government going to do about telling Australians the truth-that flights are not running at 62 per cent but at approximately 25 per cent-and increasing the percentage of flights to the west? Finally, is any port in Australia actually getting the alleged 62 per cent of flights?

—It has never been the claim that any particular port is getting 62 per cent of services. The claim is that in terms of seating capacity on the domestic airlines when they are in full operation, the current services-international services, Royal Australian Air Force and other supplementary services-are providing 62 per cent of the seats which are normally provided. I doubt very much that the figure in respect of Western Australia is 25 per cent, but I will check that and provide the honourable senator with an answer as soon as I can. In regard to the question of whether the airlines should provide better services when they are receiving what Senator Knowles calls a taxpayers' subsidy, Senator Knowles knows the circumstances of this matter as well as I do. As soon as they can provide a better service they will.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the claim that the reproduction on the latest $10 note of the Morningstar pole, designed and made by Mr Terry Yumbulul of Gove in the Northern Territory, is in breach of the Copyright and Trade Practices Acts? Can the Minister confirm the claim by Mr Yumbulul that there were irregularities in the negotiation and the subsequent agreement with the Reserve Bank for permission to reproduce the Morningstar pole? What action has the Minister taken to avoid litigation that could result in an order for substantial damages and the confiscation of all notes bearing the offending reproduction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I will leave the honourable senator's last point, with reference to the confiscation of the notes, to the bookmakers! However, I am aware of the claim. The Reserve Bank has advised the Treasurer that the Morningstar pole depicted on the $10 commemorative note had been displayed in the Australian Museum in Sydney. On the advice of the museum the bank arranged copyright clearance through the artist's commercial agent. The agent nominated a fee for the reproduction of the item as a design element on the bank note and the bank paid this fee to the agent. The bank was provided with documentary evidence that the agent had permission to deal on behalf of the artist. The fee paid was in line with those paid for other design elements in the note. Finally, the bank has assured the Government that it has sought to act properly and fairly in all its dealings in the matter. I do not know whether those representing Mr Yumbulul intend to pursue the matter any further.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Minister in the Senate for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the schedule of available airline seats for the period 18 September to 2 October as submitted to Estimates Committee B and showing Qantas Airways Ltd as having available anywhere between 1,237 and 3,143 seats as part of the claimed 50 per cent restoration of domestic flying capacity. Are these seats genuinely available without restriction to members of the public? If not, why are they being used to falsely inflate the alleged number of seats now on offer?

—I understand that they are available to members of the public in a variety of special circumstances. I will obtain an answer with respect to the number of genuinely available seats and provide it as soon as possible.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. When the Minister is checking these facts, will he also ascertain whether those seats are available only to international travellers or on compassionate grounds, such grounds requiring the production of a death certificate?
—Yes.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to the Social Security Review's Issues Paper No. 5 entitled Towards Enabling Policies-Income Support for People with Disabilities. What progress is the Government making in this area? How does the Government's reaction on these issues compare with the Opposition's recently announced policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot spell out too often that there is a very clear contrast between Government policies in this area and policies which have been quickly grasped by those on the other side. Like each of the six issues papers of the Social Security Review, the one that Senator Faulkner mentions provides, once again, careful detailed research and analysis.
—Talk to ACROD in Western Australia.

—Senator Chaney wants to intervene in this debate. We know what his credentials are like here; we know how he got rolled in his own committee. He is on record as supporting targeting in the welfare area but we know that Senator Stone has the wood on him. Senator Chaney is on record as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Recent studies on poverty in Australia clearly indicate that a substantial component of the group in Australia which is in poverty or which can be measured as being in poverty is drawn from the unemployed.

He then said that we have to isolate. He says that the only way to tackle the problem is to define the people who are in that difficult situation and direct assistance to them rather than universally increase levels of assistance at very much greatly increased cost to all taxpayers. That is the policy with which he went to his committee and that is the policy that was rejected by his committee.
Let me turn to the main point of Senator Faulkner's question. Through the Cass review we have provided a solid basis for policy development in this area. The aim of the policy direction--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I do not think I will go on unless you keep them quiet.
—Order! There is too much noise from the Opposition benches.

—As I was saying, the issues paper strongly recommends moving towards policies that reduce the dependency of people with disabilities. In the Budget this year, the Government announced its firm commitment to move in the direction suggested by the Cass Social Security Review in this area. To that extent, we have established a series of pilot projects and studies to determine the feasibility of income security arrangements to implement the social security review.

ANSWER.PARA: In summary, the Government is developing a policy in this area on a basis of paying careful attention to the facts. That is clearly different from the policy projection that was put out last week by the Opposition. The Opposition is saying, firstly, that it will maintain the eligibility criteria for invalid pensions and, secondly, that it will medically review all except those who are totally and permanently incapacitated. There are two major problems with the policy proposal put out last week. Under the Opposition's scheme, almost everybody would be medically reviewed each year. That, of course, would have major costs.

The Opposition should go back to basics-it should go back to the Social Security Act and to the criteria which apply to the assessment of invalid pensions. A medical review cannot determine eligibility. Much wider considerations, such as socio-economic and other factors relevant to capacity to work, must be taken into account. Therefore, medical review is not the only determinant. That is the first mistake that the Opposition has made. Secondly, and most alarmingly and amazingly-Senator Stone once again can smile about this because this whole policy is his work; it is etched in stone-this proposal embodies the concept of total and permanent incapacity. This concept is not within the general social security system of this country; it is within the veterans' affairs area. And there are good reasons for that. It is impossible to use that as a basis to exempt people from the review. This concept adds a further tier, another criterion, that would act to marginalise and exclude people. Thirdly, and most fundamentally, it brings into the system a concept which was discarded in 1941 by the Menzies Government following the work of a joint parliamentary committee on social security. It was discarded because it was seen then, as it would be seen now, to discourage invalid pensioners from making an effort to become self-supporting, to get back into the system, to embark upon training. So the Opposition has not only gone back, but it has gone back to a policy which was discarded in 1941.

There is another objectionable part to this policy, and I am sure that it comes from Senator Stone. The Opposition is saying that if a migrant is unable to work because of an accident-that person may have become a quadriplegic-for no rational reason but for the arbitrary prejudice that Senator Stone has embodied time and again that person will not be eligible for the disability pension. Those are not the sorts of prejudices that this Government is about. As I said at the outset, we are more concerned about a rational, comprehensive response to this problem. Our policies will not be driven by prejudice and irrationality.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. Senator Cook was reported in the Adelaide Advertiser of last Friday as saying that reducing our use of greenhouse gas generating fuels would lower standards of living in Australia. Does Senator Cook believe that the standard of living is appropriately and comprehensively measured by the rate at which energy resources are consumed? Is it not possible that substantial energy efficiency improvements could deliver the same end use service, that is, the same standard of living with lower resource consumption and lowered greenhouse gas emissions? Is it also possible that a more rigorous pursuit of energy efficiency in Australia would not only increase Australia's present competitiveness but also place Australia in a better position to capitalise on the sale of technologies, for instance recent advances in solar technology by Professor Martin Green of the University of New South Wales, which the whole world must shortly adopt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter's question enables me to clarify a point which he has clearly misunderstood in terms of what I did say and how it was reported. I do not regard, and I do not think it is reasonable that anyone should regard, energy consumption as an appropriate measurement of the way in which we determine our standard of living. That was never the implication of what I said. I did say that, apart from running programs for better energy conservation and programs that achieve greater energy efficiency-apart from those two possible strands of policy approach to reducing fossil fuel consumption-we sooner or later come to the point at which we impact upon the ability of the economy to grow.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite clearly, there is a link between energy consumption and economic growth. We as a government have been following those two prospects. It has been a policy not only of ours but of the former government. Ever since the first Arab oil price hike in 1973, governments in Australia have been concerned about greater energy efficiency and greater conservation. Under this Government it has received a particularly strong focus and it was part of what the Prime Minister said in July this year in his environmental statement. We certainly have those objectives clearly in our minds. But ultimately, if one is talking about massive reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, one is also talking about a change in economic growth targets, which is significant. I do not think that point can be avoided.

For example, I note that a 20 per cent reduction on 1986-87 CO2 emission levels by 1999-2000 implies a compound reduction in fossil fuel demand of 1.7 per cent per annum over that 13-year period. In terms of growth rates in this economy and in terms of what changes would need to be made to deliver such a reduction, we are talking about significant changes in lifestyle and in economic growth. I think that it is proper and reasonable to state that point up front, to recognise what is involved and to deal with it if we are seriously going to set those targets and reach them. Otherwise the honourable senator is engaged in a bit of hocus-pocus and black magic. The electorate will finally apprehend and see through the paucity of his position and deal with him accordingly.

The honourable senator's last question was: Would it not be better if we did more about alternative energy? Of course it would be better if we did more about alternative energy. But the honourable senator seems to imply that we have no program for promoting alternative energy projects. I would like to introduce him to the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) which, for the period of this Government, has promoted, as it will continue to promote, alternative energy research in Australia. I take this opportunity in the chamber, in a gesture of goodwill, to invite the honourable senator to the national energy awards which will be handed out by me early next month in Sydney to reward publicly scientists and those with applied alternative energy approaches for their efforts. Through those programs, working with industry and with State governments, a lot of effort had been put into finding alternative energy applications and methods. As we look around Australia we see a proliferation of some of these alternatives that just a few decades ago we would never have thought possible. The one outstanding example, which most lay people in Australia are familiar with, is the solar-generated outback telephone system that has been developed through Telecom Australia. But the essential element in all these programs is that they must be commercially viable to hold a place in the market. We, through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, are assisting in the development of that science and in its commercial application.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I will not take up the question of NERDDC; I am well aware of NERDDC and of the fact that most of the funding there has gone not into alternative energy sources. I was pleased to hear the Minister say that he recognises there is an inconsistency between the pursuit of economic growth and environmental protection. Is he saying precisely that there is an inconsistency between the pursuit of growth and environmental protection? If that is the case, to which does he give the highest priority?

—To use Senator Button's defence, as applied earlier in Question Time, I doubt whether that is a supplementary question. However, if the honourable senator reads the Prime Minister's environment statement issued in July, he will see that this Government has committed itself to the concept of environmentally sustainable development. That concept is not a slogan; a whole body of literature supports and describes what it means. The best reference I can give the honourable senator is the publication entitled Our Common Future-otherwise known as the Brundtland report, or the report of the World Commission on Environment and Development.
—Which you haven't read, Minister.

—Which I have read, Senator, and which deals with the concept of how one reconciles environmental concerns with economic and industrial development. It started out as a text for Third World countries but it is indeed a text for all countries. Just this weekend I had the pleasure of making the observation that one of the useful projects that we could adopt in this country would be to provide a comprehensive response to the concepts laid down in the Brundtland report so that our economic development is environmentally sustainable and so that we develop our economy within the capability of the resource base on which it is predicated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

ANSWER.PARA: Of much more interest to the community and to the Government is that, arising from these figures, the Government's policies have meant that 22 per cent of people who have been in this scheme have gone off benefit or had their rate reduced.
