DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1989AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering amendment No. 81 circulated by the Opposition. I remind the Committee that this seeks to amend clause 148 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. For those who are following the Bill, that clause is at page 60. The clause proposed by the Government is very brief. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Except as expressly provided in this Act, the Minister is not empowered to direct the Corporation in relation to any of its activities.

The explanatory memorandum merely repeats the clause. Since it does not explain anything, I take it that this is why it is called an explanatory memorandum. The Opposition seeks to leave out that clause, which is really quite inadequate, and to insert a clause in its place. That clause would deal with directions given by the Minister. We are talking about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation, the ATSICDC. The Opposition's amendment would propose a new clause 148 which states:
the Corporation shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.

It then goes on to make the point that that does not empower the Minister to give directions relating to the content of any advice or information that may be given by the Corporation. The clause proposes that the Minister should cause a copy of any direction given by the Minister to be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days. We propose in the clause that any such direction laid before the Parliament shall not disclose certain secret, sensitive or confidential matters.

Mr Temporary Chairman, if you are familiar with the Aboriginal Development Corporation Act, as I am sure you are, you will be aware that what we are proposing is broadly consistent with section 11 of the ADC Act which is a ministerial power to give directions of a general nature, not a power to give directions as to the content of any decision which the Corporation might take. We believe that that provision, which has existed in the ADC Act since its inception in 1980, is one that should be reproduced here. That is why we are proposing amendment No. 81. I remind the Committee again that we have had some recent experiences in Western Australia and Victoria which should give us considerable cause for concern. In Western Australia we had the experience with WA Inc. In Victoria we had experiences with the Victorian Economic Development Corporation. Each of those experiences has shown quite clearly the need for close ministerial supervision and accountability of publicly funded venture capital operations.

What we are talking about in this part of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is precisely that-it is a commercial undertaking which will involve a venture capital operation. The ATSICDC should not be at loose in the marketplace without any kind of direction-making power in the hands of the Minister. We are suggesting directions of a general kind, not specific directions. Those who have followed the ADC legislation-I am sure Senator Coulter has-will know that that general directing power has been in place precisely because the Parliament thought that such a direction-making power in the hands of the Minister was a proper thing to have. Honourable senators and members of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs will recall that the Minister used that direction-making power in May 1988 in a manner which is now quite notorious. Therefore, we have sought to take the direction-giving power of the Minister as set out in section 11 of the ADC Act and propose it for the ATSICDC. We know of no good reason why it is not appropriate and why it should not be proper to include it.

It could be alleged that such a proposal could interfere with Aboriginal self-determination. That is not the case; that could not be so. It has never been envisaged that ATSIC or the ATSICDC would operate completely divorced from the Minister of the Crown with whom constitutional responsibility rests. In any event, the Corporation is supposed to be dealing in the market on a strict business basis anyway. If ministerial directions of a general kind merely required it to do that, which is all it could do, it would merely confirm what we know is the proper way for the Corporation to operate. It would not interfere with Aboriginal self-determination. We know that it is not proposed that the Corporation Board be wholly Aboriginal. There are places for experts with particular knowledge. It is not proposed that the Minister can make any particular specific directions-that is, it is not proposed that the Minister could interfere with individual cases. We are concerned because the powers given to the ATSICDC are very wide powers indeed. They resemble in many ways the powers that were given to the Victorian Economic Development Corporation in Victoria and the powers of Western Australia Inc.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, tell us about them.

—Senator Crichton-Browne is aware of the scandal that occurred with WA Inc. The Corporation would be at large to invest in the market. Of course, it would have global but not specific approval from the Treasurer for this purpose. It would be at large in the market to make a guarantee to any person. I will come back to this question of guarantees in a moment. We propose an amendment. If it is accepted the Minister will be able to direct the Corporation in a general way-only in a general way-as to the ways in which it should operate, in exactly the same way as the Minister was empowered to direct the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). In all the criticisms I have heard of the ADC I have not once heard any criticism of the existence of that direction giving power under section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot understand some of the proposals for ATSICDC. It is proposed that it should have power to operate outside Australia. I wonder why. Is it intended that ATSICDC should become a player in international currency or futures markets? Maybe it is not, but I invite the Committee to look at the Bill as drafted. It would be possible for ATSICDC to do either of those things if it wanted to, as the Bill is presently drafted. That is why I have moved:
(81) Page 60, clause 148, lines 29 to 31, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Directions by Minister
``148. (1) The Corporation shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.

``(2) Subsection (1) does not empower the Minister to give directions relating to the content of any advice or information that may be given by the Corporation to a Minister, Department or authority of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.

``(3) Subject to subsection (4), the Minister shall cause a copy of any direction given by the Minister under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after that direction was given.
``(4) A copy of a direction laid before the Parliament in accordance with subsection (3) shall not disclose:
(a) any matter the disclosure of which in that manner would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of relevant Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) any confidential commercial information given to the Corporation.''.

I commend the amendment to the Committee. The Opposition believes that the direction giving power from the ADC is one of the clauses which it is appropriate to bring across, to copy, to transfer into this new Bill, and that this is an appropriate place for it to appear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment would be appropriate only if Senator Peter Baume and the Opposition had successfully moved some previous amendments. This is truly consequential. We are really going over ground that was dealt with in the dying hours of the debate last time we met. This would flow only if the role of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation (ATSICDC) were changed to include some of those ventures and projects which the former Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) could undertake. Here we have a body which, as is announced in clause 145 (1), shall perform its functions `in accordance with sound business principles'. It is indeed a commercial development corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Baume spoke I wondered what the content of the general directions would be. I took a note of his saying `all the Minister could properly do by way of a general direction would be to ensure that the Corporation acted in a businesslike and commercial manner'. In fact, that would be redundant; it is already stated in the clause itself. In other words, Parliament is making it very clear that the Corporation shall act in accordance with sound business principles and engage in its various commercial activities in accordance with those sorts of criteria.

When one looks at the most analagous corporation, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, one finds there is no general power of direction because it is engaged in commercial and business activity. Senator Baume's proposition would have been acceptable as a consequential amendment if, as I mentioned earlier, he had succeeded in changing the parameters of the functions, capacities and objectives of the Corporation to include some of the former ADC matters. Obviously there is no analogy with WA Inc. which was not a creature of a parliament and did not have to report to a parliament. As I pointed out last time, the Minister has the capacity to change the corporate plan, as outlined in clause 147 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989.

Under clause 147 of the Bill, the Minister may, by notice in writing to the Corporation Board, request the corporation to change its corporate plan in regard to certain matters. I think I pointed out last time that I believe that is the appropriate process for the Minister to deal with the general way in which the Corporation sets out its objectives and its method of achieving the goals and objectives under the corporate plan. Clause 147 provides an adequate capacity for the interplay which may be appropriate between the Minister and the Corporation in regard to setting its objectives in a general way. I do not believe that the analogy lies with the Aboriginal Development Commission; rather, I believe it lies with the AIDC and, for that reason, the Government will be opposing this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume. I am somewhat surprised at the comments made by the Minister in the light of evidence given on 10= October to Estimates Committee E with regard to these very issues relating to the corporate plan and the use of ministerial directions for the current Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). In April 1989 it was necessary for the Minister to issue eight directions to the ADC pursuant to section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. In pursuing a line of questioning last week in that regard Senator Short raised a number of very important issues relating to those eight directions.

SPEECH.PARA: There was quite a lengthy dialogue between Senator Short and Mr Fitzwarryne of the ADC. In summary, what came out in the Estimates Committee last week was a very unsatisfactory system with regard to the directions, and compliance with them, that the Minister had made. I was very concerned at that Estimates Committee meeting-and I hope to pursue this matter in the report of Estimates Committee E-that Mr Fitzwarryne, as an officer of the ADC, repeatedly had to take questions on notice, even though very factual requests were made with regard to complying with the necessary directions brought in by the Minister.

Similarly, the Minister has sought, by his answer just now, to rely on clause 147 in this legislation and the adequacy of formulating a corporate plan. Again, in Estimates Committee E last week there was a series of questions relating to the formulation of a corporate plan by the Aboriginal Development Commission. The ADC is currently seeking to develop a new corporate plan, and what became very apparent was that it had been done in isolation from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) task force, which has been seeking to set in place the various mechanisms that would result from this legislation.

In the various exchanges at Estimates Committee E last week a statement was made by Mr Stewart, the current Acting General Manager of the ADC, that the Commission's specific corporate plan is of little relevance to a body which has not yet commenced operations, yet the proposed corporate plan of the ADC will, in effect, forecast things for the coming five years. We all know that it is the intention of the Government that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation will assume most of the commercial operations which, for many years, have been conducted by the Aboriginal Development Commission. I am concerned that the Minister seeks to rely totally on clauses 147 and 148. It has been adequately demonstrated to the Senate, particularly at the Senate Estimates Committee last week, that there are very serious areas of concern that require the very necessary provision of suitable directions by the Minister. Amendment No. 81, proposed by Senator Peter Baume to introduce a comprehensive new clause 148, will accommodate this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Peter Baume's amendment. The clause that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) referred to really does not give the Minister any capacity to influence in any way the activities and the functioning of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. The Minister referred to the Australian Industry Development Corporation. Of course, its charter is different, its purpose for being is different and its goals are quite different. Subclause 144 (2) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, in part, states:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) For the purpose of the performance of the Corporation's functions, the Corporation Board shall have regard to the desirability of:
(a) encouraging and facilitating Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in commercial projects and enterprises;

(b) securing, as far as practicable, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in the ownership and control of companies engaged in activities that are likely to have a significant impact on Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander interests;

Paragraphs (c) and (d) continue in a similar fashion. Presumably, the golden thread running through the functions of the Corporation is the need to provide employment and activities which have a tangible bearing on the involvement of the Aboriginal community. The commercial decisions will be tempered very much by their significance to the involvement and the immediate welfare of individual Aboriginals. I assume that the first criterion will be employment prospects, the second job opportunities and the third whether there are any commercial benefits. If the first two criteria are of the most significance, I imagine that the third will be the least consequential. Whenever those types of value judgments are made it is terribly important that the Minister be required to carry responsibility because, without exception, it will be argued that, while the board ultimately made a poor commercial judgment, that judgment was very much coloured by the board's attempts to comply with the thrust of the proposals.

I would have thought, by any measure, that there ought be throughout this legislation at least proper ministerial responsibility and accountability. From my experience, one of the great problems with commercial activities that have failed and have been entered into using taxpayers' funds is that at the end of the day nobody has been held accountable. Perhaps I am in a position to judge Western Australia better than most other States. There is barely an area in my State where a commercial venture entered into by an Aboriginal community has not in some way gone adrift. The prime considerations have not been commercial merit and accountability; it seems that the criterion has been the Aboriginal being in some way involved in the activity. That criterion was thought to be reasonable. That has happened in a situation in which the Minister does have some discretion and responsibility.

More than ever there ought to be some accountability by the Minister to the Parliament of the taxpayers' funds to be expended; otherwise, there will ultimately be absolutely no sanctions at all upon the Government. The Corporation can go along merrily without having to be responsible to those appropriating the funds; and notwithstanding Senator Walsh's view, it is the Parliament and not the Executive that appropriates the funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that honourable senators can forgive Senator Crichton-Browne for intruding into the debate some quite irrelevant material. He has not been following the debate closely on this somewhat difficult area. Had he done so he would have known that ATSICDC, as now defined, is a much tighter organisation than that proposed by the Opposition and, indeed, the one proposed by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. Had this organisation been broadened, Senator Crichton-Browne's remarks may have been appropriate, but as matters stand they are not.
—That is a very subjective judgment and very presumptive about what I had to say.

—I can understand Senator Crichton-Browne going off a little half-cocked under the circumstances, and that is precisely what he has done. He has not participated in this debate. We are now considering amendment No. 81 and Senator Crichton-Browne spoke without having followed the subject properly.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. Senator Coulter is reflecting very adversely upon my contribution to this debate. He does not have the slightest idea but he gets up here and burbles away with verbal diarrhoea. It is hardly a definition of my contribution to the debate.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I remember Senator Crichton-Browne becoming involved in a debate on States rights, which was his other contribution to the ATSIC debate. I wish to make only two points regarding the amendment before us. First, I find it strange that the Opposition should object to the non-inclusion in the Aboriginal Development Commission Act of those very sections which were used by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in a way which the Opposition itself, over recent months, has been objecting to vociferously; namely, a direction given by a Minister to the ADC. The Opposition wants to carry over these very sections into ATSICDC legislation. It may well be that the Minister had used inappropriately the powers that the Opposition wants to see carried across. Nonetheless, the Opposition has objected most vociferously to the exercising of those very powers that it wants to see carried across.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point is very much in line with the Minister's remarks-that is, that, had the functions of ATSICDC been broadened to include a number of the economic development functions which were defined as those which were either economic or had it a reasonable expectation of becoming economic, it may have been more appropriate for the Minister to have a hand in the guidance of such an organisation. However, the organisation as envisaged by the Government is a very tight, almost bank-like organisation which is controlled within very strict economic limits. Despite what Senator Crichton-Browne has said, it will not contain only Aboriginal people; it can contain other people who are experts in the financial and economic areas. For those reasons, as the Minister has said, it is more akin to the Australian Industry Development Corporation, which, I would point out, was formed by the Opposition. Recently the Government saw fit to sell to private interests 30 per cent of this organisation, which has been extremely successful financially. Under those circumstances, and with that analogy, it seems that the Bill in its unamended form is the more appropriate version to support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several of the points made by Senator Coulter require a response. Firstly, it is necessary to make it clear to Senator Coulter that the Opposition can have great objections to the way in which a Minister uses a particular power and yet have no objection to the existence of the power. The Opposition does not object to the existence of section 11 directions in the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. It was our Act; we proposed it. We think the section 11 directions-the capacity to give a general direction-are well conceived. However, we did not approve of the way in which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) used that power in 1988 to sack the then eight commissioners. I think Senator Coulter would acknowledge that a distinction can be drawn, and we have done so.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at clause 148 as proposed. It is an extraordinary clause. The Opposition is not arguing simply that there should be a power of general ministerial direction; it is arguing that such a power should replace what is proposed. Part of our argument goes to the fact that clause 148 is most undesirable because it seeks to tell us that the Minister is not empowered to direct the Corporation in relation to any of its activities, except as expressly provided in this legislation. We think this is an absolutely extraordinary provision in the light of what we have learnt in the last year and a half. If we assume that there will be a new set of directors and acknowledge a capacity for mismanagement within some of the portfolio agencies, we can see that there is some advantage in using the section 11 direction-giving power in the ADC legislation. There may be a need for the Minister to have such a power.

Clause 148, as drafted, is really quite extraordinary. It reads, `Except as expressly provided . . . Minister is not empowered to direct the Corporation in relation to any of its activities'. The Minister drew to our attention the provisions of clause 147 and said that that would help to explain the matter. I am sure that honourable senators have read clause 147. They will be aware that all the clause does is permit the Minister to request the Corporation board to do certain things. That is the only power the Minister has. Clause 147 (3) states:
The Minister may, after consulting the Commission, by notice in writing to the Corporation Board, request the Corporation Board to change the corporate plan in specified respects.
The Minister has no power of direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say he did.

—That is interesting, because that was the impression that came across. The Minister suggested that the Minister had power to make a direction. But he has none at all. He can merely request. It follows that the Corporation can tell the Minister to get lost. I consider present clause 148 quite inappropriate. There are two steps to what we are proposing: first, that the clause should be left out and, secondly, that it should be replaced with another clause. The argument has two legs, and I make these comments against the background that we have already amended clause 143, which deals with the purposes of the Corporation. Those purposes are now to assist and enhance Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management and economic self-sufficiency and to advance the commercial and economic interests of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders by accumulating and using a substantial capital asset for the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I submit to the Committee that I find it quite extraordinary that we should then be asked to agree to clause 148.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is not bad enough, people have objected to our attempts to replace the clause with a provision that already exists in the nearest analogous piece of legislation. I still believe that the ADC Act is a better analogy than the Australian Industry Development Corporation legislation, which seems to me to be inappropriate. The Opposition believes that amendment No. 81, as circulated, is appropriate. We certainly do not believe that clause 148, as proposed in the Bill, is appropriate. I would love to hear some defence of it. We will, as a first step at least, seek to have amendment No. 81 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with some surprise that Senator Coulter and the Minister will not agree to amendment No. 81 replacing clause 148. Clause 148 is a cop-out for the Minister. It gives him no power at all.
—It is his estimation of what to do when things go wrong.

—I was going to come to that. It brings to my mind a bowl of water for the Minister to wash his hands in when things go wrong. We are dealing with legislation involving an immense amount of money-$900m of taxpayers' money. The taxpayer elects members of the Federal Parliament, including the Senate, to safeguard that money. I am quite prepared to acknowledge that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) must give Aboriginal and Islander people self-determination. It must let them make their own decisions. But there is also a responsibility on this Parliament and on this Committee to safeguard taxpayers' moneys. The only way that we can safeguard those moneys is to have legislation that makes an appointed Minister responsible for the spending and allocation of those moneys. Clause 148 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Except as expressly provided in this Act, the Minister is not empowered to direct the Corporation in relation to any of its activities.

I find it unacceptable that the Minister withdraws from any part in the decision-making under this legislation. It is inappropriate and incorrect for a Minister to walk away from the decision-making. I presume that the clause exists to exonerate the Minister from anything that may go wrong with this legislation. It is a complete reversal. It is going from the sublime to the ridiculous, considering the power that the Minister exercised when he sacked the previous board of the Aboriginal Development Commission. That was a tremendous abuse of power. But that does not require this legislation to take all responsibility away from a Minister.
This nation is governed by a Westminster system. As someone said, it may not be the best system in the world but no-one has ever been able to come up with a better system of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A change of government would go a long way towards changing that.

—We only have to wait two or three months for the government to change. ATSIC will be out the window and everyone will be pleased, including all Aboriginal and Islander people, who have shown their absolute astonishment that a government would come up with this type of legislation. Until that day we have to amend and make the best of this legislation. Under the Westminster system of government, Ministers are responsible for government spending. There is not a portfolio where taxpayers' money is spent that does not have a Minister responsible for the allocation of those funds. Yet we have in this legislation, this ATSIC proposal, a clause that will exonerate a Minister from all responsibility. Senator Tate has given no explanation. The reason that he has not given any explanation probably is that, even though he is a persuasive lawyer, he cannot come up with a reason why our amendment should not replace clause 148.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with great attentiveness to Senator Coulter to hear whether he could come up with some argument that would enlighten me. Unfortunately, all he could do was abuse my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne, which I thought was quite wrong. Senator Crichton-Browne was making a good contribution to this debate. He has followed the ATSIC legislation through. He has spoken on it a number of times. He certainly spoke on it during the second reading debate. I recall that he has made two or three contributions in the committee stage. I certainly am not persuaded by any argument put forward by the Government or by Senator Coulter that clause 148 should not be replaced by our amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly because I thought we had probably exhausted this matter last time and now and because Senator Crichton-Browne's rising to his feet fills me with foreboding.
—You can thank Senator Coulter for that.

—Yes. Senator Boswell mentioned that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation will have a fund of $900m at its disposal. Of course, he was referring to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. In relation to ATSIC we said that a power of general directions ought to be vested in the Minister. We have agreed to that. This is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. It is a different body. Because the honourable senator's earlier amendments were not carried, my argument has been that we are now faced with a Corporation, the structure, the purposes, the goals, the objectives and the statutory charter of which are more akin to the Australian Industry Development Corporation than to the old ADC. In fact, in relation to the AIDC, a clause similar to clause 148 is to be found in its statutory charter. So they are the real reasons. For the sake of the record I wanted to correct that particular understanding of Senator Boswell's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the Minister's quite proper correction of the figure that I think was inadvertently used by my colleague Senator Boswell. But, with respect, while that particular point is true-that the funds deployed by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation would not constitute the whole of the $900m, which, as the Minister rightly says, concerns the total area of ambit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC)-I rise to support very strongly the views that have been put by my colleagues Senator Peter Baume and Senator Boswell in opposing this clause and supporting the amendment that has been moved by Senator Peter Baume on behalf of the Opposition. While the Minister has conceded by his response to Senator Boswell that there are grounds for sufficient concern on the Government's part as to the operation of ATSIC, the Government has agreed that a power of direction should be included in the Bill to cover that-to cover the totality.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Minister that, after all, the area we are now talking about, admittedly the more confined area of the Corporation, is not negligible. I think it is in that area, in particular, that there might be the kinds of risks to which I think Senator Peter Baume and Senator Boswell have referred. One only has to think of a couple of other corporations seen operating in recent times. For example, the Victorian Economic Development Corporation has been spraying Victorian taxpayers' money around in all directions. One would think that, if there were any sense of ministerial probity left in the Victorian Government, it would have resulted in Mr Jolly's resignation long ago. Surely it ought to be acknowledged by the Minister that we have here the potential-I put it no more strongly than that-for the most extraordinary mismanagement, or perhaps even misappropriation, to occur without, apparently, there being any capacity on the part of the Minister to give directions of a general kind which would make that inappropriate.

I accept the thrust of the amendment moved by Senator Baume which is designed to ensure that any directions that are given should not allow the Minister to interfere in a particular case or a particular individual's affairs as they are being handled by the Corporation. However, I would have thought that it was crystal clear that the Corporation needs some guidelines; for example, some guidelines that might preclude it from operating in a particular area which the Government might well regard as being inappropriate. If the Government were to so regard it, the citizens of Australia might equally so regard it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can recommend changes to the Corporation.

—I will listen with interest to Senator Coulter in a moment. I take it from his intervention that he will no doubt respond to the points that have been made even much more cogently by Senator Peter Baume, but as things stand I am having difficulty in understanding why the Government should resist the amendment which Senator Baume has moved. I find it even more difficult to understand why the Australian Democrats should want to resist it because it seems to me to be no more than a normal precaution designed to buttress the desirability of fiscal probity in an area in which, it must be said, there will be no lack of potential critics looking for actions which might be thought to infringe that probity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly because I always wish Hansard to record my arguments. For reasons which escape me, Senator Coulter suggested that I had claimed that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation Board would have on it not only Aborigines, but also experts. I find that grossly obnoxious. I did not say that. I made no comment about the composition of the Board. I said that ultimately if the Minister were not held in some part accountable to the Parliament, the associated risks would be grave. We have seen that with respect to a number of matters, not the least being WA Incorporated and the like. We have also seen it in the failings of the Department. In the last couple of years it was highlighted in no better place than the Auditor-General's report. I would have thought that the amendment proposed by Senator Peter Baume was eminently reasonable. It does not seek disclosure of commercial information of a confidential or sensitive nature and it does not seek to interfere in an improper fashion. It just seeks to ensure that there is some measure of ministerial responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested to note the reference to the powers of the Minister. The proposed amendment emphatically states for all to understand that the Minister is not empowered to direct the Corporation in respect of any of its activities, as if to say, `In the event that this thing runs away at a gallop, we all want you to understand it is not a responsibility of the Minister'. If certain matters which are subsequently disclosed cause concern or anxiety to the public or the Parliament, if questions of that nature are raised in Estimates committees, the Committee of the Whole or in the Senate, the Minister can simply refer us to clause 148. The link between the Minister and expenditure ought to be much more tangible and real than that proposed by the Government. I note that thus far Senator Tate has not sought in any way to justify the proposed provisions of the Bill, except to say in some obscure way that he imagines that our anxieties, as manifested in this proposal, are of no account.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the capitalisation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. The Committee will recall that the fund of the Corporation will pick up the $20m that currently rests with the Aboriginal Development Commission. In this year's Budget Papers, it was also revealed that the Government has set out its plans in relation to the capital base of the ATSIC Development Corporation. In the last Budget, it indicated that it would be appropriating $40m over four years, starting next financial year. Whilst that matter has been alluded to in a number of other places in recent weeks, it is important to note that therefore the Corporation would initially have a capital base of $60m, which is very significant. Senator Boswell referred to the fact that the annual appropriation for the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio is in excess of $900m; however, we cannot step aside from this very important $60m capital base of the Corporation.

—I have a procedural suggestion which may help the Committee. A moment ago I mentioned that there were two questions in relation to the matter before us. The first is that we find clause 148, as proposed, inappropriate. Secondly, we have proposed an amendment to take its place. They are really two separate questions. I had the option of later moving an amendment that the clause be left out. However, there may be an easier way to do it. Amendment No. 81, circulated in my name, proposes first to leave out the clause and, secondly, to insert another clause. I put it to Senator Coulter that they are separate questions. One could look at clause 148 as proposed and say that we think that it is not an appropriate way to go and we do not want to have it. We could then form a separate view about the amendment proposed by the Opposition. I suggest to you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that you put first the question that the clause be left out. Should that be successful, the motion to insert the clause would follow as another question. In that way, I would not have to move the subsequent motion which I have prepared.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is extremely difficult to see the difference between what Senator Baume is suggesting and what is already in the Bill. Senator Baume's proposed subclause 148 (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporation shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.

All the other subclauses modify that and say that the Minister shall not do this or that, or shall cause certain things to be laid or not laid before the Parliament. The Bill already provides that the Minister by notice in writing to the Corporation Board may request the Corporation Board to change the corporate plan in specified respects and that such a proposal must be laid before the Parliament. That provides the sort of mechanism needed. I have difficulty in seeing the difference between that and `such general directions'. What precisely does `such general directions' mean? They can be only general directions. All the speakers for the Opposition have indicated clearly that the Minister cannot give specific directions; they are very general directions. They would be the same sorts of directions that the Minister would give in suggesting a modification to the corporate plan. Therefore, it seems to me that the suggested amendment to the clause, after leaving out clause 148, simply is an expansion of what is already in the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two matters raised by Senator Coulter warrant a response. The first is that if one looks at proposed clause 146 of the Bill, which deals with the corporate plan, one will see part of the answer to what Senator Coulter has just said, that is, that the Corporation shall from time to time prepare a corporate plan and that the interval of time shall be somewhere between three and five years. That provision is contained in subclause 2 of clause 146. So the corporate plan once down is not to be changed for three years. There is quite a difference because the Minister may find it necessary, for reasons which my colleagues and Senator Stone have set out, to issue a general direction one year after the corporate plan has come down. The Corporation would have no power to vary its corporate plan-none whatsoever. It is bound by statute not to.
—No, that is not right.

—It says, `at least three years'. Perhaps the Minister is saying that `from time to time' means that the Corporation could do it more often but, as we read it, it would probably be a corporate plan to last at least three years. The other point that Senator Coulter has made is that he cannot see the difference between what is in the Bill and what we are proposing by way of amendment. I will not take very long but I just say to the honourable senator that there is all the difference in the world between a capacity to request something and a capacity to give a general direction. Those who have been on either side-senior officers in the Public Service or Ministers-will know that that difference is very significant. One may request all one wishes, but the Corporation will be under no compulsion to take any notice of that request if it does not wish to, whereas where there is a power to give general direction that general direction will be obeyed. That is the difference. I am surprised that Senator Coulter could not see that. Having said that, I do not wish to prolong the debate unduly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will add a few words to what Senator Peter Baume has just said because I think it is crucial, particularly in the light of Senator Coulter's own point on the matter. Senator Coulter said that he could not see a difference between what is being proposed by the Opposition to give the Minister a power of direction in this area in general, subject to a number of qualifications which are set out in the remainder of the Opposition's amendment, and the arrangements in relation to the changing of the corporate plan. Subclause 3 of clause 147, which is the clause relating to the consideration of the corporate plan by the Minister, states that, after various other procedures have occurred:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, after consulting with the Commission, by notice in writing to the Corporation Board, request the Corporation Board to change the corporate plan in specified respects.

As Senator Peter Baume has just pointed out, that is where the Minister's power stops. He can make a request, but there is no requirement upon the Corporation to adhere to the request. There is all the difference in the world, therefore, as Senator Baume has said, between that situation and a situation in which the Minister has power to direct the Corporation in a general manner. I think that is the nub of the matter.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not proceed with the rest of amendment No. 81. Having failed to leave out the clause, there is no purpose in trying to proceed with substituting new words. It has been drawn to my attention by officers assisting the Minister that a word has been left out of an amendment to which we agreed earlier. I draw the attention of the Committee to the Journals of the Senate of 4 October 1989, page 2089, and to that amendment which was moved by me which sought to insert a new clause in the second part of clause 88 concerning secrecy. The officers have pointed out to me that the word `except' is missing from proposed clause 88a (3) (b). The subclause should read `to produce in court any document referred to in that subsection except when it is necessary to do so for the purposes of this Act, or of a prosecution for an offence against this Act'. I understand that we moved virtually the same amendment in another part of the Bill in which the word `except' was included. Therefore, I seek leave of the Committee to have that amendment adjusted to include the word `except' in the place I have indicated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Committee to move amendment Nos 82 and 83 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (82) Page 61, after subclause 150 (1) insert the following new subclause:
``(1a) The power of the Corporation to guarantee loans to a particular person is subject to the following limitations:
(a) the Corporation shall not, without the prior approval of the Treasurer, guarantee a loan of more than $1,000,000 to the person;

(b) the Corporation shall not, without the prior approval of the Treasurer, guarantee a loan to the person if the amount of the loan, together with the outstanding amounts of any other loans to the person guaranteed by the Corporation, would in total be more than $1,000,000.''.
(83) Page 61, subclause 150 (2), line 24, after ``is'', insert ``further''.
Amendment No. 82 is an amendment to clause 150 and seeks to add a new subclause (1a) after subclause (1). Clause 150 concerns guarantees. The proposed new subclause reads:
The power of the Corporation to guarantee loans to a particular person is subject to the following limitations . . .

It then sets out two limitations. In essence it says that the guarantee shall be limited to $1m either for a single guarantee or for the total of all guarantees for a person. There is a consequential amendment-amendment No. 83, which I have moved-which seeks to add the word `further' after the word `is' in subclause (2).

Honourable senators will recall the experience of the Aboriginal Development Commission in October 1988 in relation to the Woden Town Club. I recall that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand),who made great play of the fact that he had not approved any expenditure for the poker machine club, had approved the giving of a guarantee. This clause concerns guarantees and this amendment concerns the giving of guarantees. What emerged from the Woden Town Club experience was a demonstration that the giving of a guarantee can be just as much a charge on taxpayers' funds as the giving of a loan or a grant, especially when it is a guarantee which will be called in. One has to assume that the giving of any guarantee is a guarantee which may have to be met. Many of us here are parents and many of us will have had the experience of being approached by our young sons or daughters. The usual statement is, `Dad, I want to buy a motor car, and I have to get someone to guarantee a loan'. Of course, dads guarantee the loans, but we are well aware of the fact that we may end up, given the worst case scenario, having to pay out that guarantee. The giving of a guarantee implies that it may have to be met. All that the Opposition's amendment seeks to do is put some limitations on the guarantees which the Corporation may give. We say that the Corporation shall not, without the prior approval of the Treasurer, guarantee a loan of more than $1m to the person. We are reasonable people. It is not as though we are trying to limit the guarantee to $50,000 or $100,000; we are talking about large amounts of money. The real question is whether anyone should give guarantees for more than $1m. We seek to limit it in that way. Clause 150 (1) reads:
Where the Corporation Board is satisfied that money lent or to be lent to any person . . .

It conveys the impression that it is talking about guarantees to persons and we are merely saying that the guarantee should not involve more than $1m to one person without the prior approval of the Treasurer. If there were a special case, some special, exceptional circumstance, the Treasurer might well approve the giving of a guarantee for more than $1m.

I remind the Committee again of the experience of the Woden Town Club where the guarantee was called in, where the money that had been guaranteed had to be produced. A guarantee is a potential payout. We are well aware that there is a subclause in the Bill which gives the Treasurer power to influence the overall level of guarantees which the Corporation may grant, but that involves only the overall level. The subclauses we are proposing would give an added measure of control in the case of single large loans-and those are the loans that worry us. We go further because we are aware that some people are the subject of several guarantees. As a father I would look very coldly upon any proposal from any child of mine who said to me, `There is a guarantee still out but I want you to make a new guarantee'. I would be quite resistant to that request.

We propose in this amendment that the Corporation shall not, without the prior approval of the Treasurer, guarantee a loan-and we provide that special cases could be met by going to the Treasurer-if the amount of that loan, together with the amount of any other loans, guaranteed by the Corporation, come to more than $1m. One million dollars is a lot of money even today, with our devalued currency. It is a very large guarantee to be giving. All we are asking is that, in the interests of prudent and proper administration, in the interests of protecting the rights of the many tens of thousands of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who will be looking to this Corporation to make their lot better, there be some limit on the extent and level of guarantees which can be given without approval from the Treasurer. I remind the Committee that, if the Corporation at any time wants to go above the $1m limit, we have proposed in our amendment a way in which that may be done. We understand that there may be special circumstances, special occasions, and we believe that going to the Treasurer for those is good and proper public administration. We believe the amendment is one which the Committee would wish to support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments moved by Senator Peter Baume. We have just concluded the debate and lost the vote with regard to clause 148 in which we proposed that the Minister have the ability to make directions as necessary. The Opposition lost that particular debate.
—Not the debate; just the vote.

—I agree; we just lost the vote. However, the proposal now before the Committee relates to the giving of loans. Senator Peter Baume has referred to the financial situation of the Woden Town Club. This is probably a very appropriate example to use. Again, I know that it is always convenient, when we have Senate Estimates committees, to solicit new information, but at Senate Estimates Committee E on 10 October, last week, we were able to ascertain that, despite what the Minister sought to do with regard to the financing of the Woden Town Club, particularly with regard to the purchasing of poker machines, the actual finances to the Woden Town Club in the 12 months since have blown out even further. We found that the ADC is the landlord of Bonner House, in which the Woden Town Club operates. In that 12-month period the Minister made a commitment to the Parliament that there would be no financing of that nature. We have now found that the Board has, in effect, not carried out its full responsibility and collected rent for the 12-month period. The Committee will recall that in October 1988 outstanding rentals to the Woden Town Club were $68,000. We ascertained in the Senate Estimates Committee last week that, as at 31 August 1989, outstanding rentals to the Woden Town Club are now $175,000. So that is another $105,000 of unpaid rent. In effect, the Woden Town Club has not paid rent in the past 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Minister, Mr Hand, gave a commitment to the Parliament that in the financial restructuring and reorganisation of the Woden Town Club there would be no demand on this Parliament to provide the additional finance. But because of this restructuring and the fact that, in the interim, the Woden Town Club has gone into receivership, the financing of that club has now been subjected to and is caught up in various court procedures with regard to outstanding liabilities. In effect, we have found that, despite Mr Hand's assurances to the Parliament, the Woden Town Club has now been allowed, through various and devious means, to slip into arrears to the tune of another $105,000.

Whilst I appreciate that the limits that Senator Peter Baume has put forward in the amendments to this legislation go beyond this-we are talking in terms of $1m-the Commission or the Board is seeking to bypass the very directions and agreements that were reached at that time. I, therefore, fully support amendments Nos 82 and 83. They are very necessary where the Commission could be underwriting significant projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is some incorrect wording in the clause which is before us, which the Minister might care to pick up. Subclause 2 states, `the payment of which may at any time be the subject to guarantees under this section'. Surely it should be, `may . . . be the subject of guarantees', or `may . . . be subject to guarantees'. We should either take out the word `the' or change the `to' to `of'. I just raise that as a technical point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the definite article should be removed, should it not?-`at any time be . . . subject to guarantees'. I will take advice while I am talking. My major concern in relation to the amendments moved by the Opposition is that, once again, they are probably consequential. I think they were drafted at a time when the Opposition hoped to secure an expansion of the role of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation to include some of the sorts of programs that the old Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) used to undertake. Indeed, I think the defeat of that series of earlier amendments leads to a situation where the Commercial Development Corporation more clearly has a mandate, a charter. In clause 145 (1) the Parliament requires the Corporation to act `in accordance with sound business principles'. I do not want to draw Senator Stone into the debate unnecessarily, but when we go out into the community looking for members of the Board of this Corporation, structured as it now is by the Parliament in this narrowly focused way, I wonder whether we might need to take account of clause 154 (4), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Director who is not a Commissioner shall be a person who the Minister is satisfied has experience and expertise in industry, commerce or finance.

So at least six out of the nine directors have to be persons with expertise in industry, commerce or finance. How would they feel, going onto a board of this importance, if their decision as to whether a guarantee might be extended to a loan of, say, $1,250,000 had to be second-guessed by the Treasurer? If I were a leading person in the commercial, industrial or financial life of Australia and I were asked, as a matter of public service, to go onto this Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation, to give of my time and to make these important decisions and so on, I might feel that my expertise was being somewhat devalued and my role was being minimised by the fact that the Treasurer was breathing down my neck or looking over my shoulder and second-guessing my decisions, which, as required by the Parliament, were in accordance with sound business principles and in accordance with all the professional expertise I could bring to bear. As I have said, if my decision needed the concurrence of the Treasurer, to put it at its least, it would appear that from day to day I would actually be subject to the veto of the Treasurer.

I think that might lead to difficulties in putting together a good board. Basically, for that reason I feel that this provision should be resisted. I can understand some of the arguments of prudence and caution that have been put, but I really think that, with the Corporation as it is now structured and with the sort of board we would be trying to put together, Senator Baume's amendment would be counterproductive in trying to secure the services of the best people possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing that the Minister has said really reflects upon the quality or need for these amendments. The need for sound business principles does not in any way exclude our trying to limit guarantees to $1m without the authority of the Treasurer. The fact that one has to ask the Treasurer if one wants to give more than $1m in no way is a reflection upon the competence of the Board or upon the people who may be asked to serve upon the Board. I simply do not follow the argument. The question is: Do we wish to see some reasonable limit-we suggest that $1m is quite generous-put upon the guarantees which may be made to any person?

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important at this stage to put into perspective what kind of capital the Corporation will have to play with. It will not take long. We know that the ADC's capital fund will be transferred to the Corporation and that, in theory, would be available, but the capital funds stands at $20m. The last government contribution to the fund was made in 1982-83, when $1m was provided, and that was during the time of the Fraser Government. Since then, during the entire life of the Labor Government, not one cent has been paid, by way of contribution, to the capital fund. The Government and my colleague Senator Tambling talked about the promise of $40m over four years starting next year. Next year never comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly won't come for this Government.

—This Government will not be here, but if the Government wants us to believe that it intends to put money into the capital fund, why was no money put in this year? It really sits very poorly with some of the things that the Minister has said. He has modified what he has said on various occasions. In Foundations for the Future, the Minister had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Act will provide that the AEDC's capital base-
the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation was then the name of the Corporation-

shall be $60 million, of which $40 million (including the $20 million in assets of the ADC's Capital Fund) would be paid on commencement, with the remainder in equal instalments in 1989-90 and 1990-91.

That was the Minister's statement to the Parliament in Foundations for the Future. We can give that away, because that is no longer happening. In his second reading speech on the Bill, the Minister said:
The Corporation's capital base will comprise the $20 million which has been allocated to the Capital Fund of the ADC since its establishment-
I interpolate: by coalition governments-
plus an additional $40 million to be allocated over this and the next three financial years. As a consequence, the Corporation will have a very significant capital base.

There is nothing in either last year's or this year's Budget by way of contribution to the capital fund. The Minister goes on to repeat that kind of statement. Of course, the $20m from the ADC capital fund is not available to the Corporation. It is all tied up in the main asset owned by the Corporation, which is Bonner House, but there will be some income from that money. If the Corporation was to have by 1990-91 a capital base of $60m-and it will not-it might be thought that the Corporation would be able to play a significant part in encouraging Aboriginal economic development. But several things make that less likely. First, I have already mentioned that the ADC's $20m is, for the most part, already tied up in Bonner House. Second, the Corporation is not going to be allowed to use the $60m, if it ever gets the $60m-and I do not believe it will-for leverage. It cannot borrow money unless that is approved by the Treasurer. So the funds available to the Corporation are unlikely, even if the capital fund is built up, to be more than the interest on either $40m or $40m plus whatever income comes in from Bonner House. The interest on $40m, even at 15 per cent, is $6m. There have to be some administration and setting-up costs, and I think that the Corporation will be very lucky to have $5m available.

The Opposition is merely proposing that, of that very limited amount of money, no guarantee in respect of a person of more than $1m-that is, one-fifth of the annual income, as we work it out-should be possible without the approval of the Treasurer. We think that is entirely proper and that the amendment which we have moved is necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly because, despite the Minister for Justice's second thoughts, he in effect invited me to respond to his comment about what he saw as the disincentive to what one might call external directors or directors provided for under clause 154 (4).
—It is provided for in clause 152. The qualification is clause 154.
—Yes, it is subclause (4). It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A Director . . . shall be a person who the Minister is satisfied has experience and expertise in industry, commerce or finance.

That is the subclause to which the Minister was referring. He asked whether the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume, if adopted, would not prove to be a deterrent to the appointment of an appropriately qualified person under that subclause. I do not think it will. Anyone who is considering an appointment to a directorship or the offer of an appointment to a directorship of this kind emanating from the Minister will obviously have to look at the whole legislation and consider very much the body of which he is to become a director. Without in any way disparaging the likely activities of this body, I would have thought that the proposal that the guarantee power be limited to not more than $1m in any individual case would be the least of the concerns of such a person considering appointment. If I can in any way persuade the Minister, he can dismiss that worry from his mind.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter drew the attention of the Committee to a drafting error in clause 150, subclause (2). I have received advice and move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 61, subclause 150 (2), line 26, leave out ``the subject to'', and insert ``the subject of''.
I believe that that should correct the drafting error.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked in a very good-natured way why we called for a division. I had not heard any expression of view from the Australian Democrats. I had no way of knowing how they would vote. The call for a division seemed to be the only way of finding out. If the Australia Democrats have a view on some of these amendments, they might let us know what it is. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (84) Page 61, subclause 151 (2), lines 32 and 33, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclauses:
``(2) The Corporation Board shall give the Minister the information he or she asks for.
``(3) The Corporation Board may give the Commission the information it asks for.''.
I understand that the Government may be disposed to accept amendment No. 84 and I would be grateful for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we will accept it.
—It proposes to amend clause 151 on page 61 of the Bill by leaving out subclause (2) and including a new subclause which would read:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Corporation Board shall give the Ministers the information he or she asks for.
(3) The Corporation Board may give the Commission the information it asks for.

Clause 151 as currently drafted makes it clear that the Corporation Board shall give information to the Minister or the Commission. The Opposition wishes to make it quite clear that the Minister, not the Commission, has the ultimate responsibility for the Corporation. The Corporation shall be responsible through the Minister to the Parliament. As we have drafted the amendment, the Corporation shall give the Minister, and may give ATSIC, certain information. It merely makes clear again the relationship which should exist between the Corporation and the Minister. We are grateful for the indication from the Government that it finds this amendment acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment that has just been moved by Senator Peter Baume. I think it is self-evident that a body cannot serve two masters. Clause 151 suggests that the Corporation is going to have two masters. I do not think that that is conceivable. It does not make for good administration or for an appropriate allocation of responsibility. When something goes wrong-no doubt something will, assuming that this body ever comes into being-in the affairs of the Corporation, are we to have a situation where we do not know who to blame? Are we to blame the Commission for intervening in the affairs of the Corporation? Will we be able to blame the Minister? Senator Baume's amendment is directed to a perfectly proper parliamentary objective of ensuring, firstly, that we know who to blame and, secondly, that it is the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move the next amendment I have a question to ask of the Minister relating to clause 152 which deals with the board of directors of the Corporation. Clause 152 provides that there should be nine directors-a chairperson, a deputy chairperson and seven other members. Will the Minister explain how the figure nine was reached? Does the Board of the Corporation really need as many as nine members? The sums of money involved are not very large by merchant bank standards; in fact, they will be very small. By the Minister's own account, even if his previous agenda were adhered to, which it will not be, the capital fund will not reach $60m for three years yet. We are talking about very small amounts of money. The fund will not be available for investment, nor for use as leverage. Only the income will be available. Therefore, the amount of money will be fairly small potatoes. Does it really require nine members to administer such a small concern?

—I do not know precisely how the figure nine was arrived at, rather than perhaps eight or seven. Quite clearly it is desirable that there be available to this Corporation an input from the sorts of persons that I spoke of and that Senator Stone adverted to, people with expertise in industry, commerce or finance, supplemented with-or they could be the same people-the desirability of having Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders on the Corporation Board. Whilst I cannot specifically defend precisely the figure nine, I believe that the need for a full range of such interests to be represented is evident. It was evidently thought that the figure nine gave a sufficient number around the table to ensure that the important decisions to be made by the Commercial Development Corporation are considered and deliberated by a sufficient number of persons who are, or represent, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and who have the expertise which is obviously required.

(a) industry, commerce or finance; or

(87) Page 62, subclause 156 (2), line 34, leave out ``(not being a Commissioner)''.

These amendments deal with the relationship between the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation (ATSICDC) and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). The first amendment, No. 85, is one of the important ones. As clause 154 (3) stands on page 62 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989, it reads:
At least 3 of the Directors shall be Commissioners.

That imposes a requirement that at least three, and possibly more, of the directors should be commissioners. The effect of the amendment which we have proposed is that those words should be taken out and replaced with the words `Up to 3 of the Directors may be Commissioners'-not `shall be' but `may be'. If it is thought, for reasons that have to do with expertise or appropriateness, that up to three directors should be commissioners, the Minister should have that capacity but it is very hard to justify the clause as it presently stands unless one envisages a subordinate role for the Commercial Development Corporation qua ATSIC itself. If one has that view of a subordinate role, that is fair enough. But we do not; we think the relationship of the Commercial Development Corporation with ATSIC itself should not be a subordinate one. Each agency has a proper role to play, subject to the Minister and, through him, subject to the wishes of the Parliament. If amendment No. 85 is agreed to, it would tend to break the nexus between the Commission and the Corporation because a Minister might decide that one-or perhaps even none-of the directors should be a commissioner. But at least it would provide a different relationship and a different set of possibilities for the Minister.
Proposed amendment No. 86 seeks to leave out subclause (4) of clause 154 and insert a new subclause. Clause 154 (4) as it is presently written reads:
A Director who is not a Commissioner shall be a person who the Minister is satisfied has experience and expertise in industry, commerce or finance.

I believe that my colleague Senator Stone has referred to that proposed subsection already. In this amendment we propose a slightly different form of words-each director, not just the ones who are not commissioners. In a sense it is consequential upon agreement to amendment No. 85. It says:
(4) each Director shall be a person who the Minister is satisfied has experience in:
(a) industry, commerce or finance; or
(b) Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander community life or enterprises.

We seek to require that those who are appointed directors shall have some kind of qualification which is relevant to the task of the Commercial Development Corporation. As we have proposed it, amendment No. 86 would be an improvement on clause 154 (4) as it presently stands.

Amendments Nos 87 and 88 are consequential amendments. In clause 156 we want to take out the words `not being a Commissioner'. If amendment No. 85 is agreed to those words are no longer necessary. That also applies to amendment No. 88.
Amendment No. 89 seeks to amend clause 162 on page 64 of the Bill. We want to leave out subclause (3) with a view to inserting new words. At the present time subclause (3) reads:
A Director who was, at the time of his or her appointment, a Commissioner, ceases to be a Director if he is or she ceases to be a Commissioner.

If we go back to amendment No. 85 and no longer have a nexus between commissioners and directors-if the Minister may just appoint those who he thinks are appropriate, with a limit of up to three directors-if someone ceases to be a director it does not matter. There is no reason why he or she should cease to be a commissioner in those circumstances. When we looked at that we realised that it was necessary to insert more words because there could be some other anomalous situations. We propose to put in a new subclause to read:
(3) Where:
(a) 3 of the Directors are Commissioners; and
(b) a fourth Director becomes a Commissioner; that fourth Director ceases to be a Director.
That merely means that there cannot be more than three commissioners who are directors. That is quite consistent with amendment No. 85.

Finally, amendment No. 90 seeks to amend clause 164 at page 65 of the Bill by leaving out the words `including at least one Commissioner' where they appear in subclause (2). At the present time, clause 164 (2) reads:
At a meeting of the Corporation Board a quorum is constituted by 5 directors including at least one Commissioner.

It is very important that that be amended and that amendment No. 90 be agreed to. Consider what would happen if there was a conflict between the ATSIC Board and the Corporation Board. As the clause is presently drafted, ATSIC could prevent any meetings of the Corporation Board simply by refusing to allow any of its commissioners to attend. As the clause is presently drafted a quorum could not be constituted unless one commissioner was present. Again I do not think that that is the proper relationship between the Commission and the Commercial Development Corporation. If the threshold question of proposed amendment No. 85 is accepted it follows that this proposed amendment to clause 164 is a proper and necessary one. I have an indication from the Government that it may find those amendments acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of them?
—I hope so.
—Yes.

—If so, I believe that there will be a material improvement to the Bill. Given the fact that we have not succeeded in some of our more basic and important objections, we are trying to build in such safeguards and improvements as we can because we believe that the best interests of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders cannot be protected unless we do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confirm, as indicated earlier in the committee stage of this debate, that the Government will accept Opposition amendments Nos 85 to 90 inclusive. It does so on the basis that it shares the objective that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation ought not to be in any sense subordinate to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It was certainly not intended that that be the case. It is extremely important that the Corporation develop its own personality out in the arena of commercial and financial life in Australia and that it be seen to be quite distinct from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission which has its own charter in clause 17 in respect of the sort of enterprise loans and grants that it might make available. The Commission has quite a distinct role from that of the Corporation. It is important that the Corporation achieve a distinctive role-acting, as it must, in accordance with sound business principles. With the sort of board constituted in the way now indicated, with the acceptance of these amendments, I believe its distinctive role will become even more apparent than was the case in the way in which we originally drafted the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (91) Page 62, clause 155, lines 15 to 28, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Selection of Directors
``155. Whenever there is, or is expected to be, a vacancy in an office of Director, the Minister may consult the Commission about a suitable appointee.''.

This amendment seeks to leave out clause 155 and insert a different clause. Clause 155 deals with the selection of directors and what should happen when there is, or is expected to be, a vacancy in an office of director. The clause, as it is drafted, sets up an elaborate to-and-fro consultation with the Commission about who might be the appropriate appointees. I return to a point made, I think, by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in relation to an earlier amendment. The Minister envisages that some people of substantial talent and experience from the commercial or business worlds may be considered for appointment as a director. I doubt whether many of them would subject themselves to the process laid down in clause 155 of the Bill.

There will be circumstances in which there is, or is expected to be, a vacancy. As we have already agreed to the earlier amendments concerning the appointment of Directors and as we have already lessened the nexus between the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation, the amendment we are now proposing seems to be a proper one and a much simpler provision. Instead of the complicated provision in the Bill at present, we propose a provision which says that whenever there is, or is expected to be, a vacancy in an office of director, the Minister may consult the Commission about a suitable appointee. It makes it quite clear that the appointment is the Minister's prerogative and that the Commission, at most, can have an advisory role to the Minister, if the Minister so wishes. I commend amendment No. 91.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts this amendment.

This amendment seeks to leave out subclauses (12) and (13) of clause 164. We have already amended clause 164 (2) by taking out the words, `including at least one Commissioner'. As presently drafted subclause 12 states:

(2) Page 47, subclause 110 (3), lines 1 to 3, leave out ``entitling Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to vote at Regional Council elections even if those persons would not be entitled so to vote pursuant to subparagraph 99 (b) (i)'', insert ``in relation to the entitlement to vote at Regional Council elections of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders who are not covered by subparagraph 99 (b) (i)''.
