I have moved these amendments together so as to limit the amount of time which the Committee will have to consider this matter. It is interesting to note that this ATSIC debate has gone through several phases. One phase was the initial proposal and the responses which came from it. Another phase occurred during the time that the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs was meeting. This committee, on which Senator Boswell, Senator Coulter and I served, looked in great detail at many of the issues surrounding the introduction of ATSIC and the ways in which it might operate. Another phase followed the report of the Select Committee and the Government's acceptance of some, but not all, of its recommendations. Another phase was the consideration of the revised legislation.

The Opposition is entitled to believe that the Australian Democrats have a particular view in relation to the electoral roll. The Opposition is also entitled to believe that the Australian Democrats had certain minimum positions from which they would not depart. We had that view because of public statements made by the Australian Democrats through their spokesman, Senator Coulter. I select a few of the things that Senator Coulter has said to the Australian people through the press at various stages along this journey. On 12 April 1989-I think this was after the Select Committee had reported and probably after the Government had responded to the report-Senator Coulter was interviewed by Mr John Shovelan on what I think was an Australian Broadcasting Corporation AM program. Peter Thompson, in introducing that segment, said:

. . . but Democrat spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs, Senator John Coulter, told AM's John Shovelan that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will remain on the drawing board until the Minister meets all the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee.
Senator Coulter was heard to say:
We're disgusted with the way in which the Minister has proceeded with this and of course he gave no inkling whatsoever of the establishment of an interim commission of five hand-picked people.
We may have something to ask Senator Coulter later about the interim commission. Senator Coulter was asked what he was disgusted about and he said:
Well, frankly it just flies right in the face of the whole thrust of ATSIC which the Minister all along has been saying is about self-determination and self-management.

He went on to say certain other things. Senator Coulter was also quoted in an article headed `Democrats' Libs team up to force Bill changes' by Lenore Taylor in the Australian dated 23 May 1989. What did he have to say? If it is not true, Senator Coulter can tell us. It states:
But sources in the Australian Democrats and the Opposition said yesterday that they would be supporting amendments in line with the rest of the committee's recommendations-
I interpolate-that is the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs-
which were not adopted by the Government.

These include two that are not negotiable for Mr Hand: the establishment of a separate black electoral roll for the ATSIC elections, and giving a wider range of activities to a proposed ``Aboriginal development bank''.
Later the article says:

But the Democrats' spokesman on Aboriginal affairs, Senator John Coulter, has said both that he expects the legislation to pass the Senate and that he will insist on several amendments, including those rejected by the Government.

We read the newspapers and we listen to AM. We are reasonable people; when an honourable senator says something such as this we take it that he means what he says. Senator Coulter was also reported in the Canberra Times of 11 May 1989 in an article by Jeannie Zakharov. Her mother is not in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have not gone back on this, have they, Senator?
—We will test this. The Democrats have roared like lions until the wind has started to blow. Jeannie Zakharov's article states:

SPEECH.PARA: But they still want the Government to agree to further changes, the party's spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs, Senator John Coulter, said yesterday.
He said the major concern was the ``unworkable'' election system in the Bill to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
Further on, the article says:

The Government has consistently opposed both the separate electoral roll and separate preamble. But Senator Coulter said yesterday he expected Mr Hand to accept the amendments to get the Bill through.

I think Senator Coulter is right. Mr Hand will want this Bill. He will accept it with the preamble taken out. If Senator Coulter intends to proceed with the amendment which the Democrats have circulated to have the preamble removed, Mr Hand will accept the Bill. Mr Hand will also accept the Bill if there is a separate electoral roll. He will not refuse to have ATSIC. This is merely an attempt to make the Bill workable. I will come to the seven amendments in a little while. The Democrats have been very courageous whilever no pressure has been placed on them. An article in the Northern Territory News of 27 February states:
A Democrat committee member, Senator John Coulter, described Mr Hand's McCarthyist reference as outrageous and an attempt to intimidate the committee.

I remind honourable senators and members of the Committee that Mr Hand had described the Senate Select Committee as McCarthyist in its operation. Senator Coulter also said that he was furious at Mr Hand's remarks. He said that there were some recommended amendments the Democrats would consider crucial. We have already heard from some of the other articles what some of those amendments included.

We have already tried Senator Coulter out on the question of malapportionment. We put a very simple proposition to the Australian Democrats: that is, that an electoral system which proposes malapportionment of the extent which is present in the ATSIC legislation should be unacceptable. It is a shame that a Labor Government that wants the people of Australia to vote at a referendum against malapportionment for whites is willing to impose a malapportionment of this degree for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. We gave Senator Coulter the opportunity to vote on that matter because we thought that he had indicated that malapportionment was inappropriate. We were impressed by an article in the Age of 24 January 1989 by Mark Metherell in which Senator Coulter is quoted. The article states:

The Australian Democrats' member on the committee, Senator John Coulter, said after yesterday's hearing: ``If you build into ATSIC a reliance upon ministerial veto to overcome defects in disproportionate representation-
they are the words Senator Coulter is quoted as having used-
then it seems to undermine the basic principle of self-determination on which ATSIC is supposed to rest.''

We actually thought that Senator Coulter meant that, so we proposed some amendments to deal with malapportionment. We brought them to this Committee and we argued them on their merits, which is what we should be doing before this Committee in the Senate. We argued that the malapportionment was wrong and should be overcome. We were encouraged by the fact that Senator Coulter was on record as saying that he disapproved of malapportionment. But he got up and said that the Minister had told him that if he did not accept the malapportionment the Bill would not go through. It is absolutely not correct. I have been a Minister; I know the tricks that Ministers get up to. Of course he would have accepted the Bill. He simply bluffed Senator Coulter out of it by making a threat. We have all these brave statements on the public record, in the newspapers and on the radio waves, but when put to the test, nothing happened.
We now come to the matter of separate electoral rolls. This has been one concern of Senator Coulter, representing the Democrats, in all the areas we have been working together.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the Select Committee, he persuaded us.

—My colleague Senator Boswell reminds me that the matter was actually raised as a concern by Senator Coulter when on the Senate Select Committee-and, I say, a very proper concern. What he was saying about electoral rolls was correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator John Coulter has said he is committed to passing the Bills, although he is proposing at least two amendments.
The article states that the Opposition has drafted a whole lot of amendments, and this is correct. Later it states:
The Democrats are proposing to pass an amendment setting up a separate Aboriginal electoral roll . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Canberra Times, too.

They said that there should be a separate electoral roll, because there should be. Senator Coulter was very convincing. In fact, in one of his press releases, dated 15 August 1989, headed `Media release' with a note at the bottom saying that further information could be got from Senator John Coulter or Jenny MacLeod, he says-I quote his words:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is no money allocated to ATSIC prior to February next year . . . then it will be impossible to start work on an electoral roll before then.

The very arguments that Senator Coulter used in favour of an electoral roll, which he trumpeted to the country so well and so widely, are as relevant now as they were then.

The Aboriginal constituency should not trust the Democrats' various press statements or their radio statements because they make it clear that the Democrats roar like lions.
—They are wimps.

—I do not want them to be wimps. The merit of the argument lies with Senator Coulter's publicly stated position-that there should be an electoral roll for ATSIC. If someone will intervene briefly, I will continue my remarks later.

—I support the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Peter Baume. We have heard some pretty strong words from Senator Coulter, such as `outrageous', `disgusted', and `furious'. —It has about as much going for it as the Maginot line.

—We will have to wait and see. The Opposition has sought to produce some amendments which will give effect to what we understood was Senator Coulter's proposition and which we have agreed to. It has been necessary to produce seven amendments. Because they are related, I have sought to move them together and deal with them en bloc. The first amendment, which is to clause 110 at page 46 of the Bill, seeks to leave out paragraph (2) (a). Paragraph (2) (a) provides that the matters that may be dealt with in the electoral rules include the use of an electoral roll or voter cards. The Opposition is saying simply that there shall be an electoral roll so that subclause becomes unnecessary. The second of these related amendments is also to clause 110, at page 47, lines one to three. It seeks to leave out the words, `entitling Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to vote at Regional Council elections even if those persons would not be entitled so to vote pursuant to subparagraph 99 (b) (i)', with a view to inserting the words, `in relation to the entitlement to vote at Regional Council elections of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders who are not covered by subparagraph 99 (b) (i)'. If one reads those two forms of words, one sees that the words that we have proposed are superior and are desirable if an electoral roll is to be introduced. The third amendment is simply a definitional one which would appear at page 4 of the Bill. After the definition `approved Regional Council estimates', we propose to insert the following definition:

SPEECH.PARA: `` `ATSIC Roll' means the Roll established and maintained in accordance with section 101a;''.
The fourth amendment which we have proposed is to clause 99 at page 43 of the Bill, line 11. It seeks to leave out subparagraph (a) and insert the following paragraph:
``(a) the person's name is on the ATSIC Roll; and''.

Honourable senators will see that at present it simply reads, `the person is an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander'. We are saying that the person should be on the ATSIC roll, because that gives effect to one of Senator Coulter's long-stated goals. Senator Coulter has stated to me on a number of occasions-he has also done so publicly-his belief that while enrolments should be voluntary, voting thereafter should be compulsory. This amendment would be consistent with the view that he has expressed. Amendment No. 5 is to page 43, clause 99, line 17. It would leave out the words, `entitled to vote at the election pursuant to', and insert the words `covered by'. The words that are there at present are not necessary if there is to be an electoral roll. The words that we have proposed in their place are more appropriate. Amendment No. 6, which is to page 43, seeks to insert new clause 101a called `ATSIC Roll'. This is an attempt to give effect to what one might call the Coulter crusade. The new clause would read:

``101a. (1) The Australian Electoral Commission (hereafter called ``the Electoral Commission'') is to cause to be established and maintained, in accordance with this section, a roll of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders who have attained the age of 18 years.

If a person who is an Aboriginal or a Torres Strait Islander has attained the age of 18 years and applies, as prescribed, to have his or her name entered on the ATSIC roll, the Electoral Commission must cause the person's name to be entered. Firstly, a person has to be an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander, secondly, the person has to be 18 years old; and, thirdly, if that person wishes, his or her name should be entered. It goes on to say that a person can have his or her name removed, and makes the point that enrolment should be pursuant to other parts of the Bill. That takes account of the fact that there is a residency requirement as well. The very difficult position, of which Senator Boswell is more than aware, is that many people who are Torres Strait Islanders do not live in the Torres Strait and it is a question of whether people should have to have a residential qualification. The Bill proposes that and the Opposition does not propose to interfere with it. We provide for certain consequential regulations which will be necessary if there is an ATSIC roll.

Our seventh amendment is that clause 106 at page 45 which says, `Voting at Regional Council elections is not compulsory' should be left out. We want to leave it out because we were convinced, on the Select Committee and afterwards, by the power and force of Senator Coulter's arguments. His proposal was simple: voluntary enrolment and compulsory voting thereafter. I do not think I misstate Senator Coulter's position. That is what he has said publicly to anyone who would listen. Certainly many of the press listened. So we propose to take out the clause that says that voting should not be compulsory and put in new words that say: `A person who is entitled to vote at an election for the members of a regional council must vote'. We do so to give effect to what Senator Coulter has proposed. We have suggested a small sanction, a small monetary fine, for failure to vote.

When the Senate works at its best it is able to take in ideas and suggestions from all sides of the chamber. At the committee stage, in the Committee of the Whole, we are able to amend and improve legislation, to examine its clauses, as we are expected to do in this place. I remind the Committee of what I said to it last sitting. The National Aboriginal Conference election that I had to oversee was riddled with rorts, and the Ombudsman, Neville Bonner, had to declare one of the elections for one of the seats null and void. There is nothing unusual about dealing with two principles which are in conflict and recognising that one principle takes precedence over the other. In this instance, the principle of getting this legislation through in the belief that it is in the interests and has the support of the majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is a more superior principle to the principle of supporting the Opposition's amendment on this particular clause.
—Hansard, don't correct that. `More superior' is what he said.

—I thank Senator Baume. I should speak more slowly and not get quite so excited. The timing of the passage of this legislation is very important. The legislation was first suggested back in December 1987. We saw an outline of it in about April 1988. We did not see the legislation itself until August 1988. A Senate select committee then had a look at the legislation and went through it. As a result, the legislation was significantly amended. It has been before the Senate for essentially the whole of the life of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The stage has been reached where, facing a Federal election and given the difficulties faced by the Opposition's proposal in relation to a roll, it is quite clear to me that supporting these amendments at this point, at this time-I remind Senator Baume that I did not say `point in time'-could well cause this legislation to falter, either by reason of the time required to put the roll in place, if the Government should see fit to accept it and try to get it through, or by reason of the legislation having to go to the House of Representatives, being there rejected and coming back here, where legislative debating time would have to be found. The possibility is that, given the Opposition's continuing and declared opposition to this legislation, the opportunity would then exist for a considerable further delay in the debate. It is for those reasons that the Democrats are not supporting this set of amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been trying to sort out what is happening in the chamber. It appears that we are now debating an amendment to the ATSIC legislation moved by Senator Baume on behalf of the Opposition which gives effect to the unanimous decision of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs which inquired into this question, one which all members of that Committee agreed to and which is still supported by all of those members in principle and by Senator Coulter particularly. I am rather at a loss to know why he is now opposing it. I have listened carefully to try to find a reason for that.
—As distinct from excuses.

—I think that is a fair comment. I have somewhat of an interest in this matter because I am on the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters and on its sub-committee inquiring into the Aboriginal Electoral Information Service. I am very interested in the outcome of this particular measure. It seems to me that a fundamental prerequisite for any fair election is the establishment of an electoral roll which is unquestionably fair and is of unquestioned integrity. Without that we do not have a fair election.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard of three excuses. One is that there is a filibuster going on. There are a number of senators around the place who have a great interest in this piece of legislation who have not been on their feet but who have left the arguments to be advanced largely by the members of the Senate Select Committee. I reject outright the suggestion that there is any filibuster. The second excuse that has been given is that there is an election coming up and the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) does not have the time to establish an electoral roll. As far as I am concerned the AEC had better get its act together and put on staff to get the roll in order. At last there has recently been a printing of the general rolls. With all of the moneys that have been provided to the Australian Electoral Commission for sophisticated equipment no-one can tell me that it cannot establish a roll as would be required of it under this amendment. If it cannot, then it is very inefficient. I for one, as a member of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters, would be seeking a reference to inquire into the Commission's efficiency if it is suggesting that it cannot establish a roll. I have not actually heard it say that it cannot establish a roll.

The third and most important excuse that has been given by Senator Coulter is that if this amendment is adopted the Minister will reject it; not only will he reject it but he will torpedo the whole of the legislation. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is not here to tell us why he would reject the whole of the legislation if this amendment-which everybody agrees is entirely fair-is adopted by the Committee. I suggest to the Committee, particularly to Senator Coulter and the other Australian Democrats, that we should adopt this amendment. If the Bill is rejected when it goes back to the House of Representatives, under its Standing Orders, a committee of reasons must be established and members in that place have to give us their reasons for rejecting any amendment that we make to the Bill.

As an Independent senator, I have not heard anyone in the second reading debate or at the committee stage advance any reasons in principle as to why this eminently fair amendment should not be carried. We have an assertion that the Government will reject the amendment and thus reject the whole of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the Minister tell Senator Coulter in the back room?

—If that is the case, the Government has to put those reasons in writing when it sends its message back to us. The odds would be that the committee of reasons would not include that as its reason for rejecting the amendment. The procedural way to go about it is to try it. It will only take a week. The amendment has the unanimous support of the Senate Select Committee. If we pass the amendment, let it then go back to the House of Representatives where the committee of reasons can explain its reasons for rejecting the amendment. We can then consider those reasons on their merits. How can we do otherwise when the Minister has not put forward a reason-unless the Minister says today that the Government will reject the Bill? I do not think that course should be accepted by the Committee. It should be done in the proper and formal way, particularly as this Committee has acted in the most propitious way-that is, it has sent the measure to a Senate select committee, which has considered it. Surely the Government and the House of Representatives should have the opportunity to consider this amendment and then come up with reasons as to why it should be rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment and I hope that the Australian Democrats think again on this issue and adopt the amendment. In my view the amendment attempts to establish the absolute prerequisite for a fair election-that is, an electoral roll which is of unquestioned integrity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my remarks in supporting the amendments moved by Senator Peter Baume by saying that I have been privileged to listen to the finely reasoned and eminently reasonable remarks just made by Senator Brian Harradine. I want to add my comments to those he has made in asking what has produced this switch in Senator Coulter's opinions on this matter and the stance of the Australian Democrats. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I heard Senator Coulter, in an earlier intervention, put forward a couple of extraordinarily weak-indeed, just extraordinary-reasons in response to Senator Baume's remarks, as to why Senator Coulter had diametrically made a 180-degree change in his position. It was not just a minor diversion from his previous position, but a 180-degree switch.
—Five hundred and forty.
—Perhaps as Senator Tambling properly reminds me, there are more degrees on the compass. If one goes round more than once, 540 degrees might be correct-it is equally possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard Senator Coulter put forward two arguments at that point. First, he said he did not believe he could support this filibuster, as he called it, on the part of the Opposition against this otherwise to be desired piece of legislation. Let met consider that. That is a shameful comment on the part of Senator Coulter and, frankly, I am surprised that he should have made it. After all, Senator Coulter has played a valuable part in the debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill.

I have rather lost track, and Senator Baume can perhaps give me the information, but we must now have passed 140 amendments on the three pieces of legislation in the package. It was 120 or so before we came back today and the Government has agreed to a number today. For Senator Coulter to suggest in any way, let alone as explicitly as he did, that the performance of the Senate in handling this legislation has been a filibuster is, I think, shameful. If Senator Coulter wants to withdraw that comment, I would welcome it. As I say, Senator Coulter himself has contributed in a valuable way to what has been an excellent debate. In fact, I heard his leader, Senator Janine Haines, when this Bill was being debated a week or so ago and the question of its progress came up, agree that the Senate has been seen at its best in its handling of this Bill. Far from any filibuster being involved, this was the Senate working in a methodical and workmanlike way to produce at least better legislation from the shambles of a Bill that this Government, and this incompetent Minister, Minister Hand, put up to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was before the Democrats did a deal with the Minister.
—I cannot from my personal knowledge aver that that is the case, although I would have to say that all the evidence certainly supports that view. I go no further than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the second reason which Senator Coulter adduced prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner as to why the Democrats no longer feel it possible to stick by their previously proudly and, indeed, widely proclaimed public sentiments on the matters concerning the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) electoral roll, which are the subject of Senator Baume's amendments. The second reason was that, as a result of long and arduous conversation with the Minister, Senator Coulter had become convinced that the Minister, if the Senate were to accept these amendments, would not accept the Bill and ATSIC would founder. There would be many a dry eye throughout the Australian community were that the case. But that is not my point. My point is simply that that is nonsense.

Mr Hand, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, has devoted himself to obtaining this legislation throughout the last two years of this particular Parliament. He has a very big agenda in mind in obtaining it. If it is the genuine view of Senator Coulter that the Minister would drop the Bill if we, this Senate, were to put in place a perfectly proper system of electoral roll under which the elections for the Commission were to be undertaken, it is simply a mark of naivety, to use no harsher word. I seem to recall that George Orwell, when speaking of some sentiment or other, said that only an intellectual would believe such stuff; no ordinary man would be so stupid. Adapting that to this particular circumstance, only a Democrat would believe such stuff; no ordinary parliamentarian would be so stupid.

Since the dinner break we have had paraded a number of other reasons why Senator Peter Baume's amendments should not be accepted by the Senate. If I recall correctly-it was a rather confused argument; I hope I do not misrepresent Senator Coulter-the first of those had something to do with the fact that after exhaustive, critical analysis of one system versus the other, he no longer felt it possible to adopt the system he had originally argued so passionately for and, indeed, as Senator Peter Baume reminded us, had swayed other members of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs to his way of thinking. I do not want to spend more time on that other than to say that this exhaustive, critical analysis has not been deployed to the Senate this evening and, I suspect, is unlikely to be because, as Senator Harradine reminded us, what possible argument could there be against the view being put in the Opposition's amendments to produce a proper and, in a sense, electorally accountable system?

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got to have a proper roll for any system, whatever system.

—Exactly. As Senator Harradine quite rightly says, we have to have a proper electoral roll for any system to work. The only question is: what kind of roll will we have? There will be a roll as a result of the election. The only question is whether it will be a roll which we have in advance and which will therefore allow the proper procedures to be mounted on and allow people to be held accountable for or whether we have some kind of electoral rort, which is clearly what the Minister would prefer us to have.

SPEECH.PARA: The next excuse-I will not call it a reason-that Senator Coulter has advanced this evening as a further insult to our intelligence is that, because of the pressures which the impending Federal election is already placing on the Australian Electoral Commission, the Commission would not have the resources to prepare such a roll were we to enact a Bill containing these provisions which are the subject of Senator Baume's amendment. Again, Senator Harradine has effectively dealt with that piece of nonsense. I have made it plain by my interjection, which Senator Coulter was good enough to take up, that there is a good deal of dissatisfaction anyway with certain respects of the procedures of the Australian Electoral Commission. That notwithstanding, we would rather have the Electoral Commission charged with the duty of putting into place a proper electoral roll for the purposes of the ATSIC elections than not have one at all.

Senator Coulter, not content with these excuses, then proceeded to follow his Labor Party mentors even further by picking up their well-known tactic. When confessing their inability to play the ball they start playing the man. He started accusing Senator Boswell, my National Party colleague, of having done a deal with Gerry Hand. Those were his words. I wrote them down. The Democrats have the hide and impertinence to stand up in this place and accuse someone of doing a deal. My God!

What was the basis of this extraordinary charge which Senator Coulter has not yet had the decency to withdraw? I accept your ruling, Mr Temporary Chairman, that no point of order was involved when Senator Boswell quite properly took exception to Senator Coulter's quite uncalled for comment. Nevertheless, I would have thought that the intervention and the exchange would have at least given Senator Coulter the opportunity to think again and withdraw voluntarily his unseemly aspersion on his senatorial colleague.

Senator Coulter produced not the slightest evidence-not a whit of evidence-other than citing a few figures about the population of a number of islands in the Torres Strait. That was the sole piece of evidence that Senator Coulter adduced for his personal attack on Senator Boswell's integrity. I understand that when a senator rises in his place and states, on his personal affidavit, that at no time has he had a conversation with Minister Hand, let alone a conversation on this matter-unlike Senator Coulter-the proper course for the senator in question is, in all courtesy, to withdraw the aspersion he has just made. But we have not had that degree of senatorial decency from Senator Coulter this evening, an outcome which is regrettable.

Senator Coulter then went on to impugn, more generally, the Opposition's bona fides in this area. He went on to say that the Opposition has always been opposed to ATSIC. Of course the Opposition has always been opposed to ATSIC. There has never been the slightest doubt about that. Indeed, as Senator Coulter was good enough to remind us, and as I reminded him by way of interjection, the Opposition stated specifically in its Economic Action Plan document which was released only last Thursday that after the next election it will disband ATSIC-should it be in operation-saving $10m of taxpayers' money in the process, at the very least. The Opposition has made no secret of its intentions and attitudes in that regard. But moving from that to Senator Coulter's imputation that the process that is going on here tonight is somehow dishonest or lacking in integrity is an aspersion to which I object strongly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I intervene briefly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I will not delay the Senate for much longer. I thank Senator Baume for his intervention, which allows me to conclude my remarks. I simply wanted to say that by these kinds of comments Senator Coulter, I think, had begun to show himself in his true colours. What we are seeing here tonight is the Australian Democrats in their normal role as the political prostitutes of this Parliament.
—I take a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I object to the term `political prostitute' being directed at me.
—On the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: I in no way directed that term at Senator McLean.
—Senator Stone, I ask you to withdraw those remarks because I believe that they are unparliamentary.

—If I may debate the point of order for one moment, Mr Temporary Chairman, I make it quite plain-if you check the Hansard you will see this-that I directed my remarks at the Australian Democrats party. I did not direct my remarks at Senator McLean. There is no substance in his point of order.
—Senator Stone, I believe that when you direct such remarks to a party you are directing them to individuals, so I ask you to withdraw the remark.

—In deference to the Chair, I withdraw those remarks. What we have seen here tonight is an example of the Democrats' normal modus operandi, making a deal with the Government and thereby betraying everything that their official spokesman on this matter has ever said on the subject. In the process they are also betraying the Aboriginal people of this country and betraying Australia. There is not the slightest doubt that one of the chief criticisms of the Australian people of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, should it ever come into being, will be the manner in which it is elected.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Democrats are doing tonight by acceding to the views of the Minister and the views of the Labor Party in this area is handing ammunition to those in the Australian community, and they will not be lacking in numbers, who will be quick to criticise the Commission not merely on the many valid grounds of a major kind on which it can certainly be criticised but also on what I might call the mechanical but equally valid ground of how the Commission is elected. We have had Senator Coulter provide us with some seven separate reasons-or rather, to pick up my earlier interjection when Senator Harradine was speaking, excuses-for this 180-degree, or 540-degree, switch in his position. I have not found a single one of them convincing for one moment. Senator Coulter will simply have to do better than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I thought Senator Jenkins was seeking the call. I would have welcomed some contributions by another member of the Australian Democrats on what I think is a most important point of principle, particularly as it has reflected so very badly on the role of the Democrats in this place. This amendment that the Opposition has put forward is one that I am very pleased to support because, in practical terms, in future we will find with hindsight that it would have been crucial to any decent and proper operation of a system of this nature. I am extremely angry because for the past few months I have been wandering around my electorate-I remind the chamber, and in particular, the Democrats, that 30 to 35 per cent of the people in my electorate are Aboriginal people-talking comprehensively about this legislation, about the recommendations that were made by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs and about the statements that were made by the Australian Democrats. Heaven forbid that I would have ever necessarily pushed the Australian Democrats line, but on this particular issue whenever I talked to the people in the Aboriginal community I was able to detail the stance being taken by the Opposition, the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Peter Baume outlined earlier when he quoted quite comprehensively from statements made by Senator Coulter, whether in the Parliament, the media or elsewhere, they were statements on which we could rely and on which I could say to the Aboriginal constituency of the Northern Territory, `This is the position that the Australian Democrats want to take'. But we have found that the Democrats have become the handmaidens to Mr Hand. As I said earlier by interjection, they have fallen into a deal. As Senator Coulter openly admitted, he spent hours in discussions with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand. We have not heard from any other Democrat senator the views on this and the reason for the very dramatic change. The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines, the Deputy Leader, Senator Macklin, and Senator Jenkins, whose constituency is in Western Australia, will obviously have a lot to answer for, but they have not come into the chamber to explain their inconsistency on this important point of principle.

I remind the chamber of a particular recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The Committee made a unanimous recommendation at paragraph 2.130. It was made by all members of the Committee, including the three Labor senators and Senator Coulter. I can understand that Senator Collins and Senator McMullan had to toe the party line on this because of other decisions that were caught up in it, but the same reasons cannot be applied to Senator Coulter. The recommendation reads:

The Committee recommends that this population should be, in each instance, the population of people on an electoral roll. While placing one's name on the electoral roll should be voluntary, voting should be compulsory thereafter for those whose names are on the roll. The recall provisions should be exercisable only by those on the electoral roll.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the amendments seek to do.

—That is exactly what the amendments seek to do. They are totally consistent with all the statements of points of principle. If we really think about it, we need to address the question of when we first got a flag of interest from the Democrats that they had chosen to prostitute their principles on this issue. When did they decide that Aboriginal Australians would be the losers? As Senator Peter Baume said earlier in the day, the legislation will get caught up in court appeals. The determination could be made quite properly today in the chamber, where the amendments could be put into the legislation. So much for the hypocrisy of Senator Coulter's deal with the Minister because he wants to see the legislation quickly pushed through in a particular way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have not had the guts to face up to the real decisions and the disastrous implications that this will have for Aboriginal Australians. Instead, we have had the feeble excuse that it will create an administrative problem for the Australian Electoral Commission. I remind the chamber that 230,000 Aboriginal Australians will be affected by the legislation. Some municipalities in Australia have more numbers than that and they can organise a structure. While I appreciate the very diverse nature of the spread of Aboriginal people around Australia, I do not think that it would be that difficult a task, given all the other resources that the Government has been prepared to commit to the other points of principle of this legislation. Senator Coulter threw up as an excuse or a reason that in the coalition's announcements last week with regard to its tax and spending policies we had outlined a cut of $100m in this portfolio.

Let me remind the Committee of the exposes of the last 18 months that have proved the waste, the inefficiency and the maladministration. Let me also remind it of the fact that the increase, the blow-out, in the vote of this portfolio in this financial year well exceeds that $100m worth of adjustment that we would seek to make in an area that we believe could be far more efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the relationship between the Minister and his Department, none of that is surprising.

—That is correct, Senator Stone. But what about the insult to the parliamentary process that the Democrats are now proposing? The chamber's consideration of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill and of the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs defies all reason and all logic purely because Senator Coulter has met for several hours behind locked doors with Minister Hand to set up a special deal to flick this legislation quickly through the Senate hopefully this week in the hope that it will not come back.
—What form did the 30 pieces of silver take in this case?

—That is a good description. It would be lovely to find out, but unfortunately we probably will not be able to do so until next year when the Senate Estimates committees meet. I remind honourable senators that so far we have considered 84 amendments to this Bill, all of which have to go before Minister Hand for major consideration. There are probably quite a number of amendments that he will not particularly like or will not be particularly enamoured of and he may want to come back and renegotiate. He has obviously grabbed Senator Coulter by the back of the neck, roughed him up against the wall and said, `Hey, don't you touch these amendments; they are ones that I will not move on'. But the Government has not come in here and admitted that these amendments are non-negotiable. Only Senator Coulter is saying, `The Minister is telling me that these are amendments that he will do a deal with, that he will hold us to', and all the rest of it. In total, we have looked at 115 amendments to this package of legislation. As Senator Stone said, the number will soon pass 120, and probably we will end up with quite a few more either tonight or tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: We are considering a most important point of principle that demonstrates that there is no role in Australian politics for the Democrats because they cannot be trusted. I ask: Who is playing the role of Benedict Arnold to Aboriginal people throughout Australia? It is Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats. Let me remind the Committee of the important aspects of doing deals, living extravagantly, and socialising with these sorts of things. This is not a place for the Benedict Arnolds; this is a place for people who have vision in Australia and are prepared to put a commitment to Aboriginal Australians before the other deals that they have done in the backroom.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of what we have just done it is no longer necessary, appropriate or possible to move the Opposition's circulated amendment No. 93 since that was an amendment to one of the clauses that we have now deleted. I indicate to the Committee that I will not move circulated amendment No. 93 but instead will pass to circulated amendment No. 94. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (94) Page 72, clause 191, lines 5 and 6, leave out ``, or an officer of the Australian Public Service authorised by the Treasurer to give approvals under this section,''.

This is an amendment to clause 191 at page 72 of the Bill. It seeks to leave out the words `or an officer of the Australian Public Service authorised by the Treasurer to give approvals under this section'. I have an indication from the Minister that the Government would not find this amendment unacceptable and I am grateful for that. I remind the Committee that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, in its 1988 report on the then ATSIC Bill, advised the Parliament on various matters. The clause number I will quote referred to the Bill that existed at that time. The report states:
Clause 210 of the Bill allows the Treasurer to delegate to `a person' the power to give approvals for `a bank' to operate as a bank for certain purposes under the legislation.

The Committee has consistently objected to such provisions as are proposed by this clause. The power to delegate such important powers to `a person' without further qualification as to a person's position, would give the Treasurer an unacceptably wide discretion in the Committee's opinion.
The clause is accordingly drawn to Senators' attention as it may breach principle 1 (a) (iv) of the terms of reference and constitute an inappropriate delegation of administrative power.

That is really a significant report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It suggested that one of the provisions in the then Bill may have breached one of the principles under which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee operates. When we saw that we looked at the new Bill. The appropriate clause in the new Bill is clause 191. It is for that reason that we have proposed the amendment that is now before the Committee.

The problem can be resolved by an agreement to the amendment which we have proposed to take out the words `or an officer of the Australian Public Service authorised by the Treasurer', and for us to say `The Treasurer may, in writing, approve a bank for the purposes of this Act'. I am grateful to the Government for indicating that it will not object to this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we move to any further amendments I would like to refer briefly to that part of the dissenting report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs written by Senator Boswell and me. At page 11 of that dissenting report under the heading `But not all aspects are included' we make a point on which I would like the Minister's reassurance and comment. Under that heading we have made mention of a few apparent anomalies in the ATSIC package. We really just want some answers. We state:

SPEECH.PARA: By the time the Minister took office, the Government's commitment to the single statutory authority responsible for all aspects of Aboriginal Affairs had to be made.

It seemed to us that the new Commission was not going to deal with all aspects of Aboriginal affairs and we wondered about certain other activities covered by other departments of state. Can the Minister now advise the Committee on the position of Aboriginal education, employment and training activities under the former Department of Education and Department of Employment and Industrial Relations-which I think is now the Department for Employment, Education and Training (DEET)-which had some quite specific Aboriginal education and training functions? What will happen to the States grants programs for Aboriginal housing? Who will administer those and how will they be administered? What will happen to the Aboriginal Arts Board of the Australia Council? I think I have made reference to this at a previous stage of the committee debate, but no attempt has been made to explain, when we talk about all aspects of Aboriginal affairs going to the new Commission, what will happen to these particular areas, which affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people but which, at first glance, seem to be located separately and outside ATSIC. Can the Minister clarify those matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seem to recall at an earlier stage in the Committee talking about various matters to do with education and employment. It was indicated that the Department of Employment, Education and Training would be dealing with some of the matters that Senator Peter Baume has spoken of in relation to his first query about certain education and training programs currently conducted by DEET.
