SPEECH.PARA: It is true that not all expenditures, not all programs, directed at the well-being of and enhancement of the situation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island peoples will emanate from the organisations established and the processes outlined in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989. Other departments and portfolios will be making contributions, as was noted last week in Estimates Committee E. There are other portfolios contributing to the welfare of Aboriginal people, and I have no doubt that that will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —But ATSIC will have a coordination role?

—I understand it will have a coordination role, though I think-and this will probably come out in the Committee of the Whole and in the report of the Estimates Committee-the strengths or weight which one gives to that word is a difficult one. Obviously, portfolios responsible to their own Ministers will be carrying out programs which, as I say, have their own direct line of political responsibility, but the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission no doubt will be concerned to ensure that as far as possible other portfolio contributions to the well-being of and enhancement of the situation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island peoples are coordinated and supplement, within the proper confines of the other portfolios, the work which ATSIC itself is undertaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice for that answer. I now go back to clause 7 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. Does it follow that the Prime Minister could, by notices in force under clause 8, transfer all the listed functions to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission at any time? I would have thought that the answer was yes. I come to Senator Tambling's question. I go back to clause 7.
—The Prime Minister's function is clause 8.

—Under clause 7 (m) there is a capacity for a transfer to the Commission to include `such other functions as are conferred on the Commission by the Prime Minister by notices in force under section 8'. Senator Tate is quite correct that clause 8 is the Prime Minister's function, but I drew attention to clause 7 for convenience. Looking at the functions listed in clause 7, I pick up Senator Tambling's question. What will be the function of ATSIC in relation to these other matters which will not be under the control of ATSIC but will fall under other departments of state? Senator Tate mentioned the Aboriginal Arts Board being under Senator Richardson's portfolio. Will ATSIC nevertheless have a function in monitoring the effectiveness of the programs of, for example, the Aboriginal Arts Board, and Aboriginal education programs and training programs within the Department of Employment, Education and Training? Will ATSIC still have a function in developing policy proposals? Will ATSIC still have the responsibility of establishing extra consultative arrangements in relation to these programs?

SPEECH.PARA: Having identified that these are areas affecting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people which will not be part of ATSIC and which will remain parts of other departments of state, we want to be quite clear on how clause 7 will relate the functioning of ATSIC to these other areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that I indicated, by a lucky premonition perhaps, that other departments are responsible to their Ministers. When one looks at subclause 7 (1) (f), one finds that the coordinating role is in relation to advising the Minister-the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
—What about 7 (1) (b)?
—I am developing the question of coordination. Amongst others, the Commission has the following functions:

SPEECH.PARA: to advise the Minister on . . . the co-ordination of the activities of other Commonwealth bodies that affect Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders . . .

Whether or not strictly speaking a department qualifies as a Commonwealth body-I guess that is possible for the purposes of the Act-the fact is that the Commission would, as the Department does now, advise its Minister in relation to how those activities of other Commonwealth bodies might be brought into a supplementary, coordinated and fully effective means of advancing the well-being of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and of enhancing their status in our society.

Senator Baume asked about monitoring in subclause 7 (1) (b). I am trying to recall the arguments. We went through them about three weeks ago. Monitoring was simply a question of being in a position to list and understand the effect of the programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders being conducted by bodies other than the Commission. Its monitoring role will be important as far as determining the sorts of expenditures and programs which it should undertake. Quite clearly, if it finds that a program being conducted by a body other than the Commission is ineffectual, perhaps in the provision of sewerage, fresh water, health services or housing, it may conclude that it needs to provide more funding and give greater priority to those matters than it would if it found that those programs were effective. Quite clearly, the monitoring of the effectiveness of those programs is a very sensible preliminary step to determining its own programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was addressed last week in Senate Estimates Committee E. I remind the Minister of the particular exchange that took place. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Does DAA retain, under a current Cabinet decision, coordination responsibility in respect of non-portfolio expenditure?
Mr Gray, the departmental Secretary, replied:
Yes, we do. We have been given a responsibility to advise the Cabinet on matters pertaining to the programs that apply specifically in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people.
The transcript continues:

TALK.START.PARA: —Will not ATSIC be expected to assume a similar responsibility?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gray-Yes, I believe it will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it appropriate to say that ATSIC will have either direct or indirect control over the spending of approximately $1 billion per annum?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gray-I do not believe it will have control in the sense that you imply there. What we have is a role of coordination. It is not one of control, it is not one of determining. For example, there are programs in other departments even now, which you have just identified and referred to. We do not control those in the sense that we can turn off or turn on those particular programs, but we do have a capacity to advise the Cabinet in relation to the impact of those programs on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.

The issue that needs to be pursued here concerns the function of responsibility. The Minister was just quoting clause 7 (1) (f) (ii), which refers to the coordination functions of other Commonwealth bodies that affect people. This refers really to advising the Minister. Then, of course, other functions are conferred by the Prime Minister under paragraph (m) by notices in force under section 8. There seems to be a difference here between those functions on which ATSIC advises the Minister on coordination of activities and those functions on which ATSIC will report or respond direct, as under present Department of Aboriginal Affairs terms, to the Cabinet. The intention of the Prime Minister for additional functions that are subsequently conferred needs to be clarified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Tambling is seeking to establish a difference where there is not one. What Mr Gray and I have said and what I believe the legislation says is all perfectly compatible. In a shorthand way, if the Cabinet is discussing matters relating to Aboriginal advancement, it may have a submission before it which has elements from the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and the Department of Community Services and Health. Quite clearly Mr Gray was not saying that the Department somehow makes a direct submission to the Cabinet. Obviously a submission goes through the Department's Minister. All departments must make their Cabinet submissions. In fact the Minister takes the submissions to the Cabinet. The submissions may be composed for his approval by the Department, and its officers may brief him, but the Minister takes the matters to Cabinet. It is clear that, as the Department advises the Minister now in relation to matters coming up before Cabinet which require advice as to coordination, supplementation and the fully effective thrust of all Commonwealth programs in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, so too the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will take on the role of advising the Minister so that if he needs to go to Cabinet on these matters he can be advised by ATSIC as he is now advised by the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not debating a particular amendment; so it is not as though we are moving to a vote on any particular matter. But, having listened to Senator Tambling's point, I did not find the answer of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) at all convincing.
—You were not there at the Estimates Committee, Senator.

—I have heard what was said in answer to the questions. The answer means what the words say. I want to return to the point I was making about clause 7 (1) (b) in relation to the answer Senator Tate gave me about other functions which rest with other departments. The functions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) are the functions it is expected to perform. In relation to powers, section 10 (1) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has the power to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done for or in connection with the performance of its functions.

We expect the Commission to carry out its functions as given to it by statute. Those functions include monitoring the effectiveness of programs, including programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission. We sought to have those words taken out, but that is history and the words remain in there. That means that ATSIC will have a function which it is expected to perform in relation to monitoring the effectiveness of programs in other portfolios. It will be expected to monitor the work of the Aboriginal Arts Board, which comes within Senator Richardson's portfolio. On the Estimates committees we have been teasing out for some years what we mean when we are talking about monitoring the effectiveness of programs.

For a start, it means we require some explicit goals and objectives. It means that we require the development of performance indicators which relate to the achievement of those goals, and we require those performance indicators to be applied. What we will get-and we want to bring this home-is ATSIC, as a function which it is required to perform, producing performance indicators for bodies which operate in other people's portfolios. If it does not, during Estimates committee hearings we can ask how it is carrying out its function of monitoring the effectiveness of, say, the Aboriginal Arts Board of the Australia Council. We would be able to say to ATSIC, `This is what the statute provides you shall do, and we require you to do it'. There will be tremendous problems within the government. I do not wish to pursue that matter much further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise one general matter. As I indicated earlier, the Government was kind enough to provide me with a copy of its drafting instructions on the electoral procedures for ATSIC, which I read yesterday. I would like to reflect on one part of those drafting directions. In relation to the matter that was raised last week dealing with how one defines Aboriginality, honourable senators will recall that I made the point that it was highly desirable that the working definition be actually written into the regulations when they are finally drafted. I would like to draw attention to the proposed electoral procedures as they are set out in the document. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Liaison Officers to be engaged by the AEC in each polling centre and mobile polling centre . . . Liaison officers to be chosen in consultation with ATSIC (and DAA for the first election); the AEC to be reasonably satisfied that the Liaison Officers chosen are capable of making judgments about the qualifications of potential voters;
Liaison officers to have duty to satisfy themselves on the balance of probabilities whether a voter is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person within the meaning of the Act . . .
The words, `on the balance of probabilities whether a voter is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander' are particularly relevant when we skip several points and read as follows:
false certification of Aboriginality by a Liaison Officer or person certifying a postal vote, or attempts to improperly influence a Liaison Officer to be an offence under the Rules.

One of those suggestions is that the liaison officer must satisfy himself or herself, on the balance of probabilities, whether a voter is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person and, further, if a person is wrongly certified, it is likely that the liaison officer would be committing an offence by improperly or falsely certifying as to Aboriginality. It seems to me that that underscores the need to make quite clear the definition which is to be used in relation to Aboriginality, and to go well beyond the definition which is presently in the Bill. The drafting instructions go on:

It is considered appropriate that there should be some mechanism for the review of a decision of a Liaison Officer that a person is not an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person within the meaning of the Bill. Review should be to the Senior Liaison Officer for each region.
That is the mechanism. It continues:
A request for review should be made and the review determined within 8 days of the close of polling. No formalities should be required.

That is an extremely brave assumption, particularly in view of this very open, tautological definition that no formality is required and that the Liaison Officer or the Senior Liaison Officer in each region, if there is an appeal, is able to determine Aboriginality. Again, I make the plea for that working definition to be written into the regulations.

The other matter I want to raise in connection with this draft is the method of filling casual vacancies if a regional councillor retires or leaves the regional council. The method outlined is as follows:

It will be necessary for the Australian Electoral Commission to provide the Minister with a list in order of priority of unsuccessful candidates, starting with the last-excluded candidate, and ending with the first-excluded. Where bulk-exclusions occur, the authorised electoral officer will be required to determine the order of priority based on the number of votes cast for each excluded candidate or, where two candidates have an equal number of votes, by drawing lots.
The Minister will then offer to appoint the first person on the list, and if that person does not consent, will continue down the list.

In that we have a method of filling casual vacancies in which one simply runs on to the next person who would have been elected if an extra number is to be elected. For argument's sake, suppose 21 were to be elected instead of 20. The twenty-first person would become the person who, under this system, would be elected. As this is only a draft, I suggest that the most appropriate and fairest method of filling those casual vacancies would be to follow the modified system as used in Tasmania, which is the full proportional representation system. It involves a recount of the vote to find how the votes would have gone had the person retiring not been present. In view of the fact that these elections will be conducted by proportional representation one might as well go the whole way and fill casual vacancies in the fairer way rather than in the way outlined here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can reiterate my undertaking to Senator Coulter and indeed to the Committee that I will seek to find out whether the working definition which he proposes can be put in the regulations in a way which keeps the working definition obviously intra vires the Act and therefore intra vires the Constitution. I can assure Senator Coulter that that will be examined with integrity. As to false certification, quite clearly the rules would have to provide for that to be a false certification undertaken knowingly or wilfully. One would have to have a mental element there which made it appropriate that there be an offence. It would not be an objective matter. We would have to find some mental element which was of a criminal kind justifying making the false certification an offence. I am quite sure that Senator Coulter's comments on that can be taken by the advisers here and relayed to those to whom we have given drafting instructions.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that also in relation to Senator Coulter's suggestion that certainly, as he was speaking, struck a chord with me. The Hare-Clark proportional voting system in Tasmania does work well in the filling of casual vacancies. That method could be put to the Minister. I will undertake to convey that to him. Indeed, I am sure that any other suggestions which Senator Coulter, Senator Baume or Senator Harradine may have in relation to the drawing up of these rules will be useful and I undertake that they will be considered fairly by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now ask the Minister for some advice. The Opposition's amendments Nos 95, 96 and 97 may or may not be needed as they are an attempt to ensure that the Aboriginal Co-ordinating Council of Queensland may become a regional council. Senator Boswell and I have discussed the matter and it seemed to us that the Government may have moved to do that, but not on a statutory basis. We would like some advice as to the current situation so that we can examine our position.

—As I understand it, four regional councils are to be included in the zone, which regional councils would be composed largely of members of the Aboriginal coordinating councils. I think that the effect sought by statutory proposals, which Senator Baume has indicated he might wish to put to the Committee, is being achieved by this administrative means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the Opposition's intention to move amendments Nos. 95, 96 and 97. The Committee can ignore those amendments. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: (98) Page 16, clause 27, lines 15 to 28, leave out the clause.

Clause 27 is an attempt to establish an interim Commission. We have spent a lot of time today discussing electoral rules and systems. It is quite clear that what is proposed is that a first Commission be appointed-not an elected Commission but an interim Commission. It is a device to get ATSIC up and operating quickly.

If there is one thing that has come through the debate, particularly from those with whom we may not necessarily agree, it is this belief in self-management, in Aboriginal people making up their own minds. What is proposed is that the very first Commission, which will make many of the rules by which the Commission will operate thereafter, is to be an interim Commission which is to be appointed. Clause 27, for example, talks about a period starting at the commencement of the Act and ending on a day not being more than 12 months after commencement; therefore the Minister has 12 months. The Commission is to consist of a chairperson, a deputy chairperson and three other members appointed by the Minister. So this is an interim Commission which will be totally appointed and will have no elected commissioners. The chairperson could hold office for up to three years; the other four members could hold office for one year, as referred to in subclause (1).

The Opposition is quite concerned about this. We have to look at the performance of the Aboriginal Development Commission over the past 16 to 18 months, ever since the eight commissioners were sacked by Mr Hand and replaced by his own choices. From what we have seen of that group of people, we have no confidence that competence or sound judgment are necessarily the result of the people Mr Hand selects. So we believe that this clause should not be included. That would then require the Government to proceed to an election.

I say to Senator Coulter that the essential element the Democrats want in place during this Parliament is the legislation. If I were in the Democrats' position it is the legislation I would want. Whatever the results of the general election-and I imagine that we will probably form the government; however the Senate vote goes, and I imagine that there will be no single party with a majority in the Senate, looking at the arithmetic of the various States-the key to what the Democrats require now is the legislation being put in place. They do not require as an essential element of what they are trying to achieve this use of an interim commission. It is a device to get quick action. It flies in the face of everything the Minister has said about self-determination by Aboriginal people. Given the history we have seen so far, of the people in the ADC who replaced the eight commissioners, we have no confidence that this is a good or proper way to go. We have no confidence either that it will reflect well upon the long term reputation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support amendment No. 98 circulated in Senator Peter Baume's name. The effect of this amendment is that there will be immediate elections of the Commission. I do not know which way Senator Coulter is going on this, but to do anything other than to elect the commissioners of ATSIC would be a fundamental denial of their right to run ATSIC and to give self-determination and self-management. I do not know which way the Democrats are going to vote, but I hope that they stick to their original position, unlike the position they took on the roll. Senator Coulter is on record as saying on AM on 12 April:

SPEECH.PARA: We're disgusted with the way in which the Minister has proceeded with this and of course he gave no inkling whatsoever of the establishment of an interim commission of five hand-picked people.
John Shovelan then said:
What are you disgusted about?
The answer was:

Well, frankly it just flies right in the face of the whole thrust of ATSIC which the Minister all along has been saying is about self-determination and self-management. We already have the experience of Mr Hand's appointment to the ADC back in May last year and that was a complete fiasco.
John Shovelan went on to say:
Isn't this just another stumbling block placed in front of the Government's proposal?
Senator Coulter answered:
Not at all. All along Mr Hand knows that he's had my support provided that various conditions are met.

I hope that Senator Coulter is going to stick to his guns in this case and that we will not see another turnaround, which he provided us with only half an hour or so ago. As Senator Coulter said, and I could not be more explicit myself:
. . . it just flies in the face of the whole thrust of ATSIC which the Minister all along has been saying is all about self-determination . . .

I ask the Committee: How can one have self-determination when the Minister picks the five interim commissioners? It is absolutely farcical to suggest that anything like self-determination is being offered to the Aboriginal people. As one of my colleagues said, the interim commission could go for as long as 12 months. It could bring down two budgets, which would effectively give it control of ATSIC for something like two years. Certainly, the policies it set down would be in train for up to two years. I am waiting to hear what Senator Coulter is going to say about this particular proposal, but I am hopeful that he will stand by his words; otherwise the whole procedure that we are going through tonight will be a blot on this chamber Senator Coulter makes strong statements and then retracts them. I will yield to Senator Coulter now and listen to what he says about this-whether he will stick to his guns or whether it will be another backdown by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting sick of this holier-than-thou attitude from the Opposition. I remind the Opposition that during the previous session, which concluded in June, Senator Vallentine put forward a Bill in relation to the Antarctic. The Opposition and the Government both spoke vehemently as to why the Antarctic should not be protected. Within a fortnight the Opposition put forward its own motion, couched in very similar terms, to protect the Antarctic. The Government spoke against it, but within another fortnight it saw the wisdom of changing its stance. One could also look at my amendments in relation to the sales tax on recycled paper. That was opposed by both the Opposition and the Government, yet within a few weeks they were trying to jump over each other to introduce legislation to remove the 20 per cent sales tax from recycled paper. So let us not be too holy about the ability to change one's mind-for quite flippant reasons in those two cases.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the interim commission, unlike the matter of the roll, I have been persuaded to a different position. In the case of the roll, my position was that philosophically I still supported the position being put by the Opposition. There were different reasons for not supporting it. In this case, when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) tabled his statement and a number of other statements-I remind the Committee that about five were tabled within about an hour of the start of Question Time, among them, Mr Hand's suggestion that he appoint the five interim commissioners-I reacted very sharply and angrily to the Minister's suggestion and I used the words that Senator Boswell has read into the record.

However, having looked at this more calmly and dispassionately it seems to me desirable that there should be an interim commission to get this thing up and running as quickly as possible. In the process of converting the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) to the new structure, it will be necessary for the bureaucracy that will carry out a lot of that work to be responsible to somebody. It will take some time for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to be elected.

We need to bear in mind that the processes to be gone through are the education of people at the level of the regions as to what is available to them and what is expected of them, then the election of regional councils and educating them about the opportunities which are available to them and the responsibilities they have. From that process will follow the election through the zones of ATSIC and then the further eduction and instruction of the ATSIC commissioners. As everybody has pointed out, this will be an extremely onerous task placed on those commissioners. They will not be ready to assume that task for some considerable time. It seems to me that it would be quite inappropriate-this is a consideration which I did not have in mind when I reacted to the Minister's original suggestion-for the commissioners to carry out as their first task the integration of those bureaucracies and bodies which now form the DAA and the ADC. It would be much better if that process could be carried out so that when the elected commissioners are ready to take up their duties the ATSIC structure is largely in place and they can take it over.

For that reason it seems to me that now-although it did not apply then-it is quite appropriate for the Minister to appoint an interim commission which will serve for a period not being more than 12 months after the commencement specified by the Minister, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chairman may for three years.

—And the Chairman may continue for longer. As Senator Peter Baume would know, the position of the Chairman is somewhat different from the other elected commissioners anyway. In view of the setting of that 12-month time limit, it seems to me that that is, if anything, little enough time to carry out the very extensive task of integrating principally the two bodies, the DAA and the ADC, and setting the scene so that when the elected ATSIC is in place it can assume that task. My position on this matter has changed and, therefore, the Democrats cannot support alternative No. 1, or amendment No. 98, proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of Senator Baume's amendment, this is a very important matter with regard to the appointment of an interim commission. It does go to fundamentals. Once again, it highlights the compromises that the Australian Democrats have chosen to make for the expediency of getting the legislation through. The fact that the Democrats have chosen to compromise their own principles and statements that have been so well expounded in the past and brought out I think is a matter that must concern us, as I said when I was speaking earlier with regard to it. It is a matter that makes me angry because I believe the Aboriginal people of Australia have taken the Democrats at their word and on face value. This is another instance where the Democrats have proven, particularly to Aboriginal people, that they cannot be trusted for whatever public statements they have made along the way.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind the Committee that once this interim commission is in place, it operates as the Commission. One of the most important and fundamental jobs that it will have will be to determine a corporate plan. So it could well be that we will have in place an interim commission which is tying up for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission a corporate plan for a period of three to five years. Again, as I said, Senator Coulter and the Democrats have compromised self-determination and self-management-I prefer to use the term self-management-as a mechanism of achieving the proper Aboriginal process of decision making. By agreeing to the institution of an interim commission that will have the full powers and functions to develop the corporate plan which will then be in place, the Democrats have thrown away the process for years and years. Again, I remind the Committee of the deliberation that took place last week in Senate Estimates Committee E. When we were discussing the proposals for a corporate plan for the Aboriginal Development Commission, it was made very clear to the Committee that the Hand-picked group of commissioners who had been appointed in May 1988 and who currently comprise the Board of the ADC, have determined, in their own wisdom, without proper regard to the proposals for ATSIC and without any consultation, even with the ATSIC task force of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs that is currently in place, to steamroll ahead with a new corporate plan for the ADC. What confidence can Aboriginal Australians have in knowing that the group of commissioners, appointed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), is already locked into a political objective to predetermine what the corporate plan will be?

Given that the interim commissioners could well be the same bunch of characters that Minister Hand chose to appoint in 1988-even Senator Coulter has agreed that they have not measured up to any good measure of performance as a Board-we could end up with a constitution of the first Commission which will have to compromise. It will have to establish policies and principles, and it will have to pick up and determine all the initial Public Service arrangements-all of the staffing, all of the initial financing and all of the other structures. The Australian Democrats had the audacity to say that they are quite happy to wash their hands of this and sit back and watch the consequences for Aboriginal Australians, which will be disastrous. I am surprised once again that the Democrats have chosen to walk away from this group of people for whom I thought they had a particular regard.

Obviously, the Democrats have chosen not to consult with the community. Senator Jenkins has not said what consultations she has had in this regard in Western Australia. Senator Powell has not given her interpretation of any views from Victoria. Senator McLean has not outlined the provisions for Aboriginals that he has consulted throughout New South Wales. Senator Macklin has not said boo with regard to Queensland, and Senator Haines has given no representation on this issue for Aboriginals in South Australia. Senator Peter Baume from New South Wales, Senator Boswell from Queensland, Senator Crichton-Browne from Western Australia, I from the Northern Territory and other senators have been having discussions for months on this issue. I believe we are properly reflecting views and concerns, and the political dilemma that will be posed by an interim commission. The sheer raw politics that will be evidenced by the manipulative manner of Minister Hand in the initial setting up of ATSIC will have disastrous consequences for Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I addressed Senator Coulter's commitment previously. I asked, in hope rather than in expectation, that Senator Coulter do the decent thing and say, `Yes, I made that commitment and my Party is prepared to stick to it'. I am not surprised that Senator Coulter has withdrawn the previous commitment he made to the Aboriginal people. I am disappointed, though.
—What about the commitment you have withdrawn over the last 48 hours?
—I invite Senator McLean, if he has anything to say, to stand up and say it, otherwise he should shut up. His contribution to this debate has been absolutely zero.
—Order! Senator Boswell, I will chair this session, not you.

—I invite Senator McLean to make a contribution. I wish he would not just sit there and snipe at people who are trying genuinely to do something for the Aboriginal people. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has told us that the Government is determined that the Aboriginal people will achieve self-determination. We have been told by Senator Coulter that ATSIC, with its faults and all, will be better than what we have now and that it will give the Aboriginal people some say in their affairs. But, unfortunately, for the next three years, the Minister--
—Hopefully not for three years.

—If the legislation goes through in its present form we could have, for up to three years, a chairman appointed by the Minister telling the elected members what the Government policy is. For up to 12 months we will certainly have commissioners being appointed by Mr Hand; he will have the power to hire and fire them. They will be appointed by him and beholden to him. So the countless hours of debate in this chamber and the hours spent by the Senate Select Committee in travelling around Australia to try to get the best out of this ineffective legislation will all be wasted.

SPEECH.PARA: We are coming out of this debate now without the roll that the Democrats promised and with unelected commissioners, appointed by the Minister, who will no doubt get their riding instructions from the Minister. A corporate plan will be set down and any hope of self-determination will be lost. The whole legislation now becomes an utter farce, thanks to the Democrats. We may as well not have even started. With this legislation there will be no roll, no self-determination and no prospect of ever lifting the standing of Aboriginal people. I suppose we should not go into politics if we get disappointed by such things; we should just let them roll over us. But this is disappointing, although not surprising. It is the last straw for the Aboriginal people. They never wanted ATSIC in the first place. The Minister went around and told them that it was the only way they could ever make decisions for themselves. He even sold it to some people. But when he said that there would be an appointed commission, they lost all faith in any promises that the Minister had made. They saw through the whole shoddy charade of the ATSIC legislation. But they did have some hope; they did not believe that the Democrats would cave in. They thought that at least Senator Coulter could keep one promise. How disillusioned they will be that Senator Coulter could not stand up for them even on this one issue and let them have their self-determination, their elected representatives and democracy in their communities. They will not get that. Mr Hand will elect the commissioners and, if they do not do as they are told, he will sack them and send them home in disgrace, as he did with the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission.

This legislation is not worth even the paper it is written on. It is a charade, a fraud and a disappointment. Consequently, Aboriginal people will walk away from it as though it is the plague. The fate of this legislation hangs on what the Democrats do. If the Aboriginal people cannot make an input, if they cannot have a roll and if they do not know who will be elected, they will treat this legislation like they treated the National Aboriginal Conference. They will walk away from it; it will be just another piece of white man's legislation that they do not understand and do not want to know about. It will not deliver them anything and it will be a farce.

I am disappointed, but not as disappointed as the Aboriginal and Islander communities. I think they will take out their vengeance on the Democrats who have enjoyed some small electoral support from them. But I do not think the Aboriginal people will touch the Democrats with a 40-foot barge pole after having been sold out so badly by them on this legislation.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (99) Page 16, subclause 27 (1), line 20, leave out ``Minister'', insert ``Governor-General''.

The Committee will realise that amendment No. 99 was to be moved only if amendment No. 98 failed. What we are seeking to do with amendment No. 99 is amend clause 27 by leaving out the word `Minister` and inserting the word `Governor-General' at line 20. That would then mean that the appointments of the interim commissioners would be, as it were, made by the Executive Council.

I remind the Committee very briefly of the situation that arose in May 1988. Although the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) was able to sack eight commissioners, he was not able to sack the chairperson and one other commissioner because they had been appointed by the Executive Council. They were Governor-General appointments. What emerged from that little exercise was the enormous vulnerability of those appointees of the Minister and the relative security of the appointees of the Governor-General.

If Senator Coulter is now convinced that it is appropriate to appoint an interim commission, we put to him that the Governor-General-that is, the Governor-General in Council-should appoint the commissioners. The appointments would go through Cabinet and the appointees would be given a security and a protection which they deserve and which history shows can be useful. History also showed us last year the inappropriateness of the Minister having the sole prerogative to make these appointments. We commend amendment No. 99.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly to the matters which are covered by amendment No. 100. I might move it in a moment. We are discussing the Bill as a whole. The Opposition has been very unhappy with the performance of the notorious acting commissioners who were appointed to replace the people sacked in May 1988. I am not going to take the time of the Committee to rehearse each of the matters that have come to our attention.
—Feel free, Senator Baume. Help me to refresh my memory. Refertilise the activity of my brain.

—I think most honourable senators will recall the litany of disasters that came before Estimates committees and before the Senate during the last year, of loans that were made on inadequate documentation, of money that was given in areas within which those acting commissioners had a personal interest, and of loans which have been disastrous in their effect. We have already talked about the Woden Town Club and the fact that the guarantees that were given there have had to be called up. We should at least address ourselves to the manifest failure of that group of people. I would hope that the Minister, in his wisdom, would not want to appoint those people who have failed so badly to administer what was an established Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) with a good administrative infrastructure and established procedures. Those acting commissioners, when associated with the ADC, turned it into an area of disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: Reluctant as I am to direct criticism towards individual people, I have to say that we must look at what happened, look at the results that occurred and look at the actual events that are recorded. Those notorious acting commissioners have performed abysmally. The Opposition is concerned as to how it should proceed because it does not believe that they should become members of this interim commission. Of course, it is a different matter when we talk of the first elected Commission. That will be a matter for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. If they want to elect someone such as Ray Robinson-actually they cannot elect him at the moment but they can elect someone like him-then that is a matter for the electors. I do not wish to look behind the kind of choices they might make. Our concerns relate to the interim commissioners, who will not be elected and who will then reflect the judgments of the Cabinet and the Governor-General in Council, and the performance and record of the acting commissioners who have been there since 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment. I notice that Senator Baume has not actually moved the amendment. He has quite rightly, in the Committee of the Whole House, taken the opportunity to signal some concerns of the Opposition. I make the plea that in the end he does not move this particular amendment. It is really a surprising provision to be found in a statute. It could be thought to be somewhat vindictive.
—Oh!

—Senator Stone should allow me to continue my remarks. I did not adopt that word myself, as he quite often does in debates. He places the thought on somebody else's lips. The fact is that it could be thought to be vindictive in relation to people who have been asked by the Minister to undertake a task. Senator Baume says that they have discharged the task notoriously badly.
—You are doing it quietly, in a good-natured way.
—Let us be more honest in relation to this particular amendment. It is couched in a very objective way. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not be appointed under subsection (1) if he or she was appointed to act as a Commissioner of the Aboriginal Development Commission on or after 12 May 1988.

It might have been more up front, more open, to have drafted the provision to say: `The following persons, being persons appointed to act as Commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission on or after 12 May 1988, are not to be appointed under subsection (1)'. Then the persons concerned could be listed. It is like an act of attainder under the Stuarts or the Tudors. Those parliaments had the capacity, apparently, to name certain persons, and terrible consequences followed.

If this were done in a more open way it would amount to the listing of certain individuals and persons and saying, `They are precluded from office because they accepted an appointment offered to them by a Minister to discharge a task on behalf of the Aboriginal community'-in this case with the Aboriginal Development Commission. I find it quite extraordinary that people like Mr Lui Junior, whom Senator Boswell would know well, the very respected Chairman of the Island Coordinating Council, should be precluded by dictate of this Parliament from serving on this interim Commission if it be the will of the Minister. I do not know that it is his will; I have no idea whatsoever. But I believe that Mr Lui would not wish it to be thought that Senator Boswell would vote for a provision which precluded him from participating-and I am sure that is not the intention of the Opposition. It is signalling a concern but I do not think that it will move the amendment.

What does one say, for example, about listing Lois O'Donoghue? She is a remarkable woman by any standards who is performing an extraordinarily difficult task at the moment but doing it extremely well. We know that she was the foundation commissioner of the Aboriginal Development Commission for four years and has been an acting commissioner for the last 15 months. Senator Boswell has spoken of her role on the Aboriginal Hostels Limited Board over many years. I do not need to remind the persons who are involved in the committee stage of this debate of her qualifications, personal integrity and the high regard in which she is held-so much so that she is a member of the Order of Australia-indeed, a member of the Order of Australia Council.

I ask the Opposition, which has indicated its concerns, not to move this particular amendment because I believe that it could be misinterpreted in the Aboriginal community in a way which could become very personalised in regard to very good Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, two of whom I have mentioned. It would be a very remiss step for this Parliament to agree to a clause which, as I say, has more to do with the Tudor and the Stuart parliaments than with an Australian parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am impressed by the reference by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to Lois O'Donoghue and to Gaetano Lui Junior. I first met Lois O'Donoghue in 1974 or 1975 when I was a member of a Senate committee under the chairmanship of a former senator, the late Jim Keeffe. Lois O'Donoghue accompanied us to Oodnadatta on quite a memorable visit where former Senator Jean Melzer distinguished herself in defence of the Senate committee system. Lois O'Donoghue is a distinguished Australian. I think that some of the other people who have been appointed on or after 12 May 1988 are known to be distinguished Australians. But the fact is that the Aboriginal Development Commission has performed abysmally by any test one cares to make of its performance. Its decisions have been bad, partial, unfair, self-serving and vindictive. That is what the Commission has been like. Its treatment of Shirley McPherson--
—Disgraceful.
—Its treatment of Mick O'Brien has been disgraceful. These people, however fine they are personally, were either ineffectual--
—One has to ask why they are still sitting in this Commission.

—They chose to remain in it while it was making decisions like that because they did not care, they did not try or they could not succeed. Those are the explanations. If there are bad decisions and good people associated with them, that is a tragedy in itself.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns the Opposition is that this plea from the Minister-which we think is not unreasonable-contrasts markedly with the actions of the Minister himself in the treatment he meted out to the eight people he sacked. Those of us who were on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs-Senator Coulter, Senator Boswell, I and other members who are not in the chamber-consider that those sacked Commissioners were treated shamefully. Senator Tate has just referred to the fact that if people are treated in this way their reputations may suffer in the community. Goodness me! What happened to the reputations of the eight sacked commissioners? The Senate Select Committee met a very fine person who came before it. She said, `When I went home people said, ``What have you done wrong?'' `. They assumed that she would not have been sacked had she not done something improper or wrong-that she had been cheating, or something like that. Of course, we care about the way she was treated, but the Minister did not, and if the Minister did not then the Government did not.

The matter was compounded because at about the time that they were sacked a very disgraceful event occurred. A story was leaked from somewhere centrally placed, somewhere with a fax. It appeared in the second edition of the Sydney Morning Herald and it alleged that a large amount of money had gone missing from the ADC and was unaccounted for. The fax turned up in Alice Springs at almost the same time. There was a concerted effort to discredit those dismissed commissioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —To blacken their names.

—To blacken their names in ways which were improper and disgraceful. Senator Tate is correct in expressing some tender concern for the Lois O'Donoghues and Gaetano Luis, but there has been no expression of concern from any member of the Government.
—What tender concern was he expressing when you were asking questions about that matter earlier this year?

—Senator Stone is absolutely right. We went to some lengths to try to protect those dismissed commissioners. The report of the Senate Select Committee-I do not have the page open, but my colleagues will tell me if I am wrong-even recommended that some remedial work remained to be done to assist these people. The Committee recommended that, even at the late stage at which the Committee reported, it was incumbent upon the Minister to do at least two things. The first was to add to the absolutely minimal letters of appreciation that had been sent to the commissioners, which they required to maintain their standing in their own communities.
—Yes.

—Senator Coulter is right; we did recommend that. We further recommended that a public statement be made by the Minister, on behalf of the Government, acknowledging that the story which appeared in the newspaper was incorrect, without foundation and required refutation.
—Then they were left out of the annual report.

—Senator Tambling reminds me of something I had forgotten. When the annual report was prepared it showed the degree of pettiness which had come into the whole scene. I accept the admonition of Senator Tate, that we should have some concern for the reputations of these acting commissioners. I say to him that it would convince us more if the Government, of which he is a part, and if his colleague, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, had shown some matching concern for the commissioners who were dismissed so unnecessarily, and who were disgraced within their own communities in ways which were inappropriate, unnecessary, and really quite vicious. In view of all that, the Opposition will not proceed to move, argue or persist with proposed amendment No. 100 which has been circulated in its name.
—Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate some correspondence that I received last week concerning the activities of Australia Post. This concerned me greatly, as it concerned many members of the Victorian electorate and I am sure the Australia-wide electorate. I refer to a letter that I have received from a constituent in Victoria concerning the delay in her receipt of a telegram from Austria advising her of the death of her brother. I have not had the opportunity to show the letter to Senator Reynolds, the Minister on duty. I would be very happy to pass the letter to her, and I hope that she will allow me to have it incorporated in Hansard. It basically advises Australia Post of the fact that her only brother passed away suddenly in Austria last month and that the telegram which was sent from Austria on the morning of 21 September was not received by her, for a variety of reasons, until 26 September. The letter points out that the telegram advising my constituent of the death of her brother was received by her five days after its dispatch from Austria. By that time not only had her brother died but also his funeral had taken place. As she says in her letter, this caused her great distress and embarrassment. She said that her relatives in Austria found it hard to accept that an overseas telegram would take five days to be delivered. I seek leave to have that letter, with the name deleted for personal reasons, incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr Paul Smith,
Post Office Liaison Officer,
G.P.O. Box 2020,
Melbourne. 3001.
Dear Sir,

I write to say how distressed and bitterly disappointed I am with your telegram service. My only brother passed away suddenly in Austria and my relatives sent me a telegram informing me of this sad event and details of his funeral from Newmarket, Austria, at 11.30 a.m. 21 September. This telegram was received by me today 26 September at 2.00 p.m. in the ordinary mail. The number of the telegram is 00093-086674-01. From my inquiries I was told that the telegram was received in Melbourne at 10.00 p.m. on 21 September and was posted to my address from the West Footscray Post Office on 22 September.

A death in the family is a difficult time and in my case it has been even more difficult because of your delay and lack of service. My relatives in Austria believed that the telegram would be delivered immediately on its receipt in Australia. It is of great concern to me also that this is probably not the first time, or the last time, something like this has happened or will happen in a time of death and distress.
I would be grateful to receive your comments and explanations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have written to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, drawing his attention to this fact. I have raised it in the Senate because it involves some very important issues of principle that relate to us all. A human fact of life has been exposed where, for whatever reason-and it would seem to be for reasons of less than perfect efficiency and operation-a government agency has caused considerable distress, embarrassment and concern to a person in Australia. If this were a one-off example I would perhaps be less likely to raise it in the Senate, but I find that there are increasing concerns expressed among my constituency in Victoria about the state of affairs with Australia Post and the delivery of services in my State. I would assume that that is not confined to Victoria but is Australia-wide.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise this matter in the hope that the Minister and, through the Minister, the Government will look at the efficiency and operations of Australia Post in particular but of other government agencies as well in terms of their delivery of services. Although this is perhaps a small example it is a very important one for the persons concerned. I think that it is indicative of concern about the operations of government agencies, particularly in the area of telecommunications-Australia Post and Telecom Australia-in relation to the services that we have traditionally come to expect them to provide to the people of Australia.

In that context I put to Senator Reynolds and, through her, to the Minister responsible, my considerable concern about the continuing rumour of Australia Post having a hit list of post offices and postal outlets around Australia. This rumour was probably at its peak in January this year. Despite denials from Australia Post, in January this year it was revealed through freedom of information provisions that there are proposed policy guidelines for the closure of Australia Post outlets throughout Australia. A figure of 240 outlets has been mentioned in the press. I do not know whether that figure is correct or not, but I do know that the guidelines were contained in a letter from Australia Post to the General Secretary of the Union of Postal Clerks and Telegraphists almost exactly one year ago from today. I am not sure that the contents of that letter have been made public, but on 28 October 1988 a letter to the General Secretary of the Union of Postal Clerks and Telegraphists from Mr Flynn, the Director of Retail Operations of Australia Post, contained as an addendum proposed policy guidelines for retail facilities in postal outlets in Australia.

Those guidelines said, among other things, that for provincial centres-which were classified in that category as having a population of between 10,000 and 100,000-the retail revenue was to be sufficient to cover full retail costs; that is, break even. The Australia Post guidelines for towns with fewer than 3,000 people were that the retail revenue was to be sufficient to cover 80 per cent of full retail costs.

Australia Post and the Government must tell the people of Australia, particularly those in non-metropolitan areas, whether those guidelines-which the press have called a hit list-are realistic guidelines in the sense of their being worked towards by Australia Post. Or does Australia Post deny those guidelines and claim that there are other guidelines or policy directives operating in relation to the postal facilities in this nation? If one believes the guidelines that were made available only through freedom of information, then one would say that the hit list that has been alleged in the media and elsewhere is, in fact, a hit list. It is an indictment of this Government that-to my knowledge-the Government has not been prepared to say whether this is or is not a list of the criteria on which postal facilities will operate.

If the guidelines that I have read out tonight are accurate in the sense that they are guidelines on which Australia Post will operate, they will have an enormous impact on regional and rural Australia. Regional and rural Australia has a right to know whether that is the area in which they are operating. If those guidelines were introduced, their impact would be considerable. I pay tribute to my colleague the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Alston, who has pointed out in press releases over the last couple of weeks that the re-emergence of speculation about the downgrading of rural post offices and Australia Post facilities will be resolved only when Australia Post outlines specifically what it proposes. So I ask the Government, through the Minister at the table tonight, to take on board what I have said and to bring back to the Parliament, and therefore to the Australian people, a clear indication of what is proposed so far as the future of postal facilities in rural and regional Australia is concerned.

That is the second part of my comments tonight. The first part, as I said earlier, related to the approach I have had from a very distressed and embarrassed constituent. Her family is overseas, and her problem concerns what seems to me to be an unconscionable delay in the receipt of a vitally important personal message through the overseas telegram service, operating in this case between Austria and Australia. Almost all of the delay has been occasioned at the Australian end. I demand that the Government give that constituent, through the Senate, an answer to that question and also look very seriously at the wider issues I have raised tonight because, in the end, our ability to communicate amongst ourselves, particularly the ability of the rural and regional areas of this country to communicate with each other; affects the lifeblood of this country. It is not an insignificant matter by any means. It is a matter that the Government should be coming clean on in a way that it has not been prepared to do to date.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.45 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 7 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister been briefed on the Defence Department's DESINE contract.
(2) Does the Department of Finance have a representative on the Defence Computer Acquisition Council.

(3) Was the Department's representative at the Acquisition Council meeting that approved DESINE; if not, what external scrutiny was undertaken to ensure that all costs as well as benefits were identified.
(4) Does the Department of Finance have any reservations or objectives to DESINE and the way it is being implemented.
(5) Has the Minister been informed of the additional costs to the taxpayer resulting from the implementation of DESINE.
(6) Does the Minister agree that he has some responsibility to ensure that for any acquisition in Government, the lowest cost-effective solution should be sought by open tender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, before the contract was awarded.

(2) There was no Defence Acquisition Council for DESINE. Acquisition Councils are convened for each major computing acquisition proposal. The DESINE proposal did not commit to any specific level of purchase and therefore did not come under the Acquisition Council process. Nonetheless, specific major acquisitions, which are being progressed under the DESINE concept, such as the Supply Systems Redevelopment Project, are each subject to Acquisition Council processes and these involve officers from my Department.

(3) As stated, there was no Acquisition Council for DESINE. The tenders were examined by the Defence Source Definition Committee which, on this occasion, included representatives of the Department of Administrative Services, Industry Technology and Commerce and the Attorney-General.

(4) Finance considered Defence's decision to proceed with DESINE to be justified. Some reservations were expressed at the time about having one major supplier for the bulk of Defence ADP acquisitions for five years. These were addressed by Defence and balanced against the potential benefits from improved capability of systems.

Finance is strongly supportive of the development of OSI, which has the potential in the longer term to reduce the lock in to any particular supplier. It is noted that acceptance of OSI is an element of the DESINE concept.

As to implementation of DESINE, it was Defence's expressed intention that DESINE should not preclude the adding to existing (non-DESINE) equipment where a DESINE solution would not be economic at this time. Finance understands that the contract provides exemptions from the sole-supplier status of IBM, where solutions covered by the contract would be clearly unsuitable in terms of functionality or time or where excessive project cost is involved, which would appear to give effect to this intention; Finance would be concerned if it did not.

(5) No. My officers' advice was that information provided from Defence indicated that, on the basis of Life Cycle Costs, for indicative purchase quantities specified in the Request for Tender, the IBM offer was the cheapest and most cost-effective.

(6) I agree that I share with other Ministers the responsibility to achieve the lowest cost-effective solution. I consider that my particular responsibility is best discharged by establishing an appropriate framework to promote good decision making. This is achieved through promulgating regulations and guidelines which provide guidance on procedures and other aspects of decision making. Open tender is a desirable process and should be the norm, but may not always be practicable or the most appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 September 1989, Senator Chapman asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the Government has decided to provide fully maintained motor vehicles for the use of Senior Executive Service (SES) level public servants? Does the Minister agree that this decision could amount to anything from a 10 to 15 per cent pay rise on top of what these officers will receive in national wage adjustments? Is this decision consistent with the wage guidelines that the Government is so determined to protect in the pilots dispute? How many such cars are being provided? Is it correct that the public servants have the option of purchasing their vehicles at the end of two years or 40,000 kilometres? If so, will they buy them at normal commercial value or at the depreciated figure taken from a Commonwealth sales tax free original purchase price? Will he in due course provide the Senate with full details of the decision, the extent of its implementation and the guidelines which apply so that the public can make an assessment of how the provision of this facility to its own employees sits with Government's rhetoric about other pay claims?

In my reply, I undertook to provide the Senate with full details of the decision to introduce the scheme, the extent of implementation and the guidelines which apply. The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following response (and the response is sub-divided for convenience):

(1) Senior Executive Service (SES) officers in the Australian Public Service now have access to Commonwealth owned private plated vehicles for private purposes under clearly stated terms and conditions. The vehicles are not for the exclusive use of the participating officers. They must remain available for operational requirements of official Commonwealth use, including by other staff, during office hours, and SES officers who choose to participate are required to make a personal financial contribution towards meeting the costs of private use of the vehicle.

Participation by SES officers in the scheme is optional, and is a conditional entitlement. The personal contribution is currently set at $500 per annum for those officers who choose to drive a 4-cylinder vehicle and $700 for a 6-cylinder vehicle. Participating officers may choose from a specific range of standard, fleet-type cars, fully maintained, which as far as possible comply with the Government's passenger vehicle manufacturing plan.

The provisions are modest in comparison to many private sector schemes, which frequently provide luxury cars for the exclusive private use of executives without the requirement for any financial contribution, and other public sector schemes.

The Government believes that the limited provision of cars for SES officers will assist in retaining skilled and experienced senior officers, while in no way conflicting with the Government's commitment to the adherence to National Wage Case Guidelines in the area of SES pay.

The Coalition would apparently go further. The current Coalition Public Administration Policy document proposes terms and conditions of employment in the public sector broadly comparable to those in the private sector. It also proposes market loadings in addition to the terms and conditions determined by the Industrial Relations Commission.

(2) Approximately 1600 SES officers are eligible to participate in the scheme. As some eligible officers will elect not to participate, and others will gain access to existing Commonwealth vehicles converted to private plates, a lesser number of new vehicles is required. Final details are therefore not available.

(3) SES officers will not have an option to buy the cars at the end of two years or 40,000 kilometres. Rather, when the vehicles are being replaced, approximately every two years, the used vehicles will be sold by DAS at public auction.
(4) I table a copy of Guidelines on the Private Use and Registration of Commonwealth Vehicles, which sets out in full the provisions which apply.
